Most of us who are not creatively adept can produce interesting graphics with Canva — within a few minutes. 

Be it party invites, birthday cards, or even an investor presentation!

Before Canva, how did we do this? 

Those who were technically adept perhaps used Photoshop or Illustrator, the rest had to hire someone to do our graphics. 

That’s where Melanie Perkins saw the opportunity. 

She didn’t have a tech background. She wasn’t from Silicon Valley. She started in Australia, a country far removed from the tech epicentres of the world. 

Yet, she was propelled by a deep sense of purpose. She believed that design shouldn’t be for the few but for all. And Canva was born. 

Today, it is a platform that has revolutionized and democratized design, but it wasn't as easy as it looked. 

Let’s rewind. 

Melanie’s first entrepreneurial gig started in Perth, Australia selling scarves to her classmates. Later, while studying at university, she noticed how cumbersome designing yearbooks was.

Soon, she launched Fusion Books as a platform enabling users to design and print yearbooks effortlessly.

Fusion Books became the largest yearbook publisher in Australia and even expanded to France and New Zealand.

Melanie envisioned a platform to make design universally accessible, intuitive, user-friendly, and most important, simpler. 

It was a rocky road. 

She pitched Canva to over 100 venture capitalists. The answer was almost always no.

It was only after refining her pitch and showing persistence that Bill Tai funded Canva in 2013. And partnering with ex-Google engineer Cameron Adams brought a solid technical backbone to the platform.

After the initial funding, Canva was launched as a graphic designing tool and offered drag-and-drop features, a vast template library, and an interface so simple that anyone could use it.

Within a year, the platform had over 750,000 users, disrupting traditional design giants like Adobe.

In the next 2/3 years, Canva raised $71M in Series A funding, launched its first iPad app and introduced Canva for Work.

By 2018, it hit 10M users, raised $40M, and became a unicorn with a $1B valuation. 

By 2021-22, the valuation was $40B, with 125M users, crossing $1B in annual revenue. And this year the user base further went up to 200M.

It remains a privately held unicorn and one of the most valuable modern startups in the world. One of a kind startup story, for sure!

Melanie’s resilience and clarity of purpose became the bedrock of Canva’s phenomenal success. 

Did you know - she is one of the youngest self-made billionaires, with a net worth of $ 4.4 billion (2024)?

At times it may feel that the world may be stacked against us, but this growth story sends out a loud message that your purpose and drive must outweigh the rejections, setbacks, and all the reasons people say no.

Because, sometimes, it takes consistent persistence to change everything.

It’s a normal day. You're crossing the street, when suddenly the wail of an ambulance siren pierces the air. 

As it speeds closer, its high-pitched screech startles you. But as it zooms away, the sound seems to slow down, the pitch dropping into a deeper groan. 

This in & out of sound reminds me of an interesting concept of physics known as the Doppler Effect.

Named after Austrian physicist Christian Doppler, this effect explains how the frequency (or pitch) of a sound wave changes when the source of the sound moves relative to an observer.

When the ambulance is far away relative to the observer, the waves are spaced evenly. But as it approaches, each sound wave gets compressed, and we hear a higher pitch. Once it passes, the waves stretch out, and the sound becomes lower.

This isn’t limited to just sound, though! 

The Doppler Effect applies to any type of wave, including light. Astronomers use it to study stars and galaxies, measuring how the light waves change to determine if a celestial object is moving toward or away from Earth. 

This shift in light waves—called "redshift" when moving away and "blueshift" when approaching—helps scientists understand the universe’s expansion.

From racecar engines and train whistles to helicopter blades, the Doppler Effect is all around us.

The Doppler Effect not only adds a layer of science to everyday experiences but also has crucial applications in various fields.

In medicine, Doppler ultrasound helps visualize blood flow, capturing the movement and speed of blood cells in our bodies. And in meteorology, Doppler radar helps track storm movements, essential for predicting severe weather.

The beauty of the Doppler Effect lies in its simplicity and ubiquity!

This seemingly small concept stretches across vast fields, from the sound of sirens to the mysteries of space.

So, what else in our everyday world could be hiding a bit of science like the Doppler Effect? 

I have always been curious to the mysteries that surround us.

Middle child syndrome but for countries.

Not quite struggling for survival like the underdeveloped, nor basking in the privileges of the developed – 108/195 countries belong to Middle-Income Countries. 

Their gross national income (GNI) per capita lies between $1,136 and $13,845. Spanning from Brazil to Turkey to India, they represent the economic bridge where
➡️ 75% of the world’s population resides and
➡️ contributes to 40% of global economic output

Yet, many find themselves stuck in a conundrum.

Economists call it the "middle-income trap." 

The trap is simple yet complex.

As of 2022, India has seen a significant reduction in poverty rates, from 80% in 1947 to approximately 11% in 2022. (Source: The/Nudge Institute).

Where countries achieve significant growth lifting millions out of poverty, only to hit a ceiling! They can no longer compete with low-income nations on costs, nor can they innovate fast enough to rival high-income economies.

This is the economic equivalent of being outpaced by both younger siblings and older overachievers.

To understand the challenges of these middle-income nations, imagine an uphill climb with multiple obstacles:
1️⃣ Productivity plateaus: Early growth often comes from industrialization and cheap labour. But to move forward, these countries must embrace high-value industries.
2️⃣ Inequality and governance: Wealth gaps widen, eroding social cohesion and creating political instability. Weak governance further stalls progress.
3️⃣ Infrastructure deficits: While roads and ports might support basic industries, they often fall short of advanced manufacturing or digital economies.
4️⃣ Education and skill gap: Education systems often fail to equip workers with skills for tech-driven economies.
5️⃣ Environmental challenges: Rapid industrialization takes a heavy toll on natural resources and complicates sustainable development.

Despite these hurdles, history offers hope. 

South Korea and Singapore successfully escaped the middle-income trap and transitioned into high-income status by focusing on three core pillars:
➡️ Education: They prioritized human capital and ensured their workforce was ready for the future.
➡️ Technology and innovation: By embracing cutting-edge industries, they secured a competitive edge.
➡️ Economic diversification: Relying on a single industry was not an option. They took their bets and spread them too.

India, with its vibrant democracy, young population and immense potential has the ingredients to break free.

How can we accelerate the process for India to leap forward? When do you foresee India breaking out of the trap?

You can tell a lot about a person by their Pinterest boards.

My Pinterest boards? Fine embroidery, house decor, green construction, landscaping, and lately wedding decor.

Pinterest has quietly become a marketing powerhouse.

And a lot of social media platforms are full of negativity and rage-baits. But as per Sprout Social’s 2024 content strategy report, "more than half of social users think of Pinterest as 'more positive' than other platforms." In general, we strive for concurrence and consensus. 

In most situations that is the bedrock of social harmony. 

Innovation on the other hand propels a society forward — but comes at the cost of tension, resistance to change, and short term chaos. 

Any idea that challenges the status quo is bound to create tension. 

That tension isn’t a sign of failure. It’s a sign that you’re touching on something deep rooted, something that might be difficult to imagine and embrace for many people. 

Like in a garden, uprooting a tree may take different effort based on species, season, and its root system. The power to shift perspectives, systems, or ways of thinking is exhilarating but not an easy task.

People instinctively react to new ideas based on personal proclivities. It might feel too big, too risky, or too dumb. 

It is human nature. We’re wired to be cautious, to guard against failure. 

As an innovator or entrepreneur, you must be able to make believers out of skeptics. You have to accept these reactions as part of the process. 

A new idea, especially one that promises to upend established systems or assumptions, feels threatening. 

For an idea to be world-changing, it has to venture into the unknown. 

Pay attention to the doubts and questions, not as roadblocks but as opportunities to grow your communication skills. Let it fuel your determination. 

The ideas that seem impossible at first are often the ones with the power to change everything.

It also required some pretty smooth stones. I remember we used to walk by the railway tracks near my aunt's house, searching for the perfect stones. The best ones were found by the tracks—rounded and smooth, polished to a sheen by the weight of passing trains. Riverbeds were another source of such treasures. And when we found that perfect round stone, the feeling couldn't be matched by any treasure! 

What a source of pride these stones were! We would trade our stones with friends, envying those with a better collection than us. 

This memory came back to me when I came across this anecdote about Steve Jobs, which has already gone viral on LinkedIn. In this video, you see him explain how a set of rough-cut stones became beautiful polished stones through friction. He uses those as a metaphor for teamwork.

For me, it reminded me of how the simplest things can teach us so much. We found joy in playing with a handful of pebbles for hours on end. Joy in trying to get better at a game. Joy in just playing it with a group of friends. It’s funny how such small, simple moments from our childhood stay with us, quietly shaping who we are.

As Obama's speechwriter, Terry wrote nearly 500 speeches on topics ranging from global security, human rights, international economics, and of course, US foreign policy. The heart-racing drop. The gut-wrenching loops. The adrenaline-pumping speed.

Nothing quite matches the rush of a roller coaster! I used to love getting on one in my childhood and today would not venture on one.

We know they’re thrilling, fun, and maybe a little nerve-wracking.

But have you ever wondered how they actually work? Surprisingly, it’s not as complicated.

It's all about physics. As the coaster climbs the initial hill, it's gaining potential energy – energy stored due to its height. Think of it like winding up a spring.
 
Once you reach the peak, that stored energy is released, transforming into kinetic energy – the energy of motion. This energy propels the coaster down the track, building up speed as it descends.

The coaster's design is crucial. The loops, twists, and drops are carefully calculated to ensure a smooth and thrilling ride. 

Engineers consider factors like gravity, friction, and centripetal force to create a safe and exhilarating experience.

In fact, playground swings operate on the same principle, albeit on a much smaller scale.

As kids, we would take turns on the swing, always in pairs, one sitting and the other standing and propelling the swing. 

Remember how you crunched down and pushed the swing out and leaned in to enjoy the ride down?

When you’re at the highest point, you’ve stored the most potential energy. As you swing down, that energy becomes kinetic, propelling you forward. The harder you swing, the more energy you generate—a small-scale version of what happens on a roller coaster.

Roller coasters feel like the perfect way to embrace chaos while still knowing it will safely roll into the station at the end. 

It's a perfect combo of fear and exhilaration, and hence they're so popular.

So next time you’re screaming your lungs out on a coaster, take a moment (if you can) to appreciate the science beneath the thrill. 

Because in every twist, every drop, and every loop, the universe’s rules are hard at play, the laws of physics making every ounce of excitement.

Someone recently asked me about my New Year’s resolutions. 

My answer? 

To stick to routines and rituals. To live an ordinary life consistently.

It might seem an odd resolution, but it's one that gives me meaning at this stage of my life.

Growing up, I saw how routines ground us. 

In a constantly shifting world, they offered stability, a sense of sameness, purpose, and control. Good day or bad, we would wake up, do our morning chores, pray, and then have breakfast. That was just how life worked, and that consistency taught me how the simplest of routines and rituals can give us so much power. 

As I reflect on the year ahead, I was reminded of this BBC article I read about the role of rituals. I've shared the link in the comments.

Research shows that rituals are beneficial, boosting our mental health and improving our connections. Routines aren't just habits. A habit can be impersonal, a task to be completed. But a ritual has a deeper emotional connection. 

For example, the ritual of lighting a lamp at night and getting up in the morning to still see the light glowing gives me immense comfort. Taking time to write every Sunday afternoon in silence provides me with clarity. Even clearing my house before a gathering or a festival feels like resetting to a new beginning. 

These are ordinary moments, yes, but they offer us space to breathe in and contemplate. 

And some rituals create shared memories. My father, even late into his life, would make it a point to host the annual family gathering. At that time, I wondered why he made such an effort. Today, we remember those gatherings with fondness and realize that, in his own way, my father was guiding us toward the joy of community. 

I remember, too, my mom's ritual of making ghee at home, the aroma of freshly made ghee filling our house. 

We have rituals around food. Around prayer. Even service and giving.

So, if you ask what I am looking forward to this year, it's just this: To seek solace and comfort in time-honored rituals. Small moments like these:

➡️ Cleaning the diyas, which fills me with so much joy
➡️ Gathering family and friends for festivals to maintain the traditions I grew up with
➡️ To indulge in self-care, a leisurely oil massage on Sunday, a childhood ritual I cherish
➡️ Lighting the evening diya, pausing to feel grateful that this light exists and that life will unfold tomorrow

This year may bring chaos and calm. Beauty and ugliness. We don't know, but while we wait for time, I intend to look at the threads that have given me meaning all my life: those ordinary rituals that hold us together. 

We underestimate the power of rituals in our mental well-being. 

Perhaps, to sustain an extraordinary life, we need some ordinariness. 

I wish you a year of joy, meaning, and purpose.

Winning a Nobel Prize is a high honor, the pinnacle of recognition. Yet, imagine this: Nobel prize winners are told just minutes before the official announcement. If you happen to miss that call, the next thing you know, you may be reading about yourself on the news. And even if you don’t miss the call, these calls are stories in themselves.

The story goes that structural biologist and Chemistry laureate Venkataraman Ramakrishnan was in a particularly bad mood after a flat tire caused him to arrive late to work. His office told him that there was an important call from Stockholm. An angry Venkataraman thought it was a prank and didn't believe it until he finally got on the call and realized that the call wasn't fake at all. 

Martin Chalfie, who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2010, slept through the phone ringing. He got up around 6 am to find out that he won the Nobel Prize after millions had read the news. Chalfie turned to his wife and said, "It's happened." His wife, more absorbed in the everyday humdrum of life, replied, “What? Have we overslept while taking our daughter to school?”

The 2024 economics science winner, James Robinson, likewise slept through the call. His wife saw it first on the news and was woken by her. Most American winners would find themselves grappling with the time difference, perhaps, when that call comes from Stockholm.  

Barry Marshall, who won the 2005 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, got the famous call at a pub! That must have been some celebration! Richard Ernst was on a flight and was informed by the plane's captain that he had won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Julius Axelrod heard about it while sitting in his dentist's chair! I wonder if that would have made the procedure less painful after the news! ;-)

What fascinates me is that laureates are completely unaware they’ve been nominated. The Nobel Committee doesn't announce the names of nominees to the media nor inform the candidates under consideration. Those who nominate a candidate aren't allowed to disclose that for 50 years!

Apparently, these high achievers are like the rest of us in terms of imposter syndrome. Many Nobel Laureates wonder if they were good enough, if they deserved it, like Steven Chu did. 

"I feel like any day someone is going to realize they made a mistake and fire me," he said. Physicist Barry Barish confessed he had imposter syndrome. And that's the thing, isn't it? You can reach the heights of your career, the pinnacle of achievements, and still wonder if you deserve it. Fascinating.

Reminds me that even though the Nobel Prize Laureates are geniuses in their fields, they are also so human. A reminder that doubt is part of the process and that wonderment is part of the reward.

Climate change is a problem of the future, something perhaps our grandchildren will be affected by. But by then, the governments, technology will find some solutions — or so we tell ourselves. But what if it is an unprecedented crisis in our times? 

For the first time in recorded history, global temperatures have consistently crossed thresholds that scientists warned us about for decades.

2024 the first year to breach the 1.5 C global warming limit.

And 1.5 degree Celsius temperature change is a crucial threshold. It is a pivotal point, for the worse.

Research indicates exceeding this point could trigger big and potentially irreversible negative impacts on the planet's ecosystems, making it a critical point to limit global warming to avoid the most severe consequences of climate change. This threshold is recognized by the Paris Agreement.

As an investor and entrepreneur, I’ve always believed in the power of human ingenuity to solve complex problems. It’s painful to see the destructive consequences of inaction on such a monumental issue. And even more painful to read from climate deniers. And we have many of them leading global governments.

What are economic ambitions without a healthy planet? If we have cancer ravaging our body, what use is the value of accumulated wealth?

➡️ Heatwaves, scorched landscapes, and weather patterns so erratic they defy predictability.
➡️ Oceans, the lifeblood of our planet, are warming to levels they cannot sustain. 
➡️ Glaciers are retreating, sea levels are rising, and coastal regions are inching closer to catastrophe.
➡️ Hurricanes and typhoons batter coastal areas with fury that grows year after year.
➡️ In contrast, droughts parch the soil in other regions, erasing crops and forcing people from their lands. 

And so much more.

Sustainable innovation isn’t just about finding the next green technology; it’s about rethinking how we operate, how we consume, and how we prioritize the future over short-term gains. The data this year tells us that we are running out of time to bridge that gap.

These are not isolated tragedies; they ripple across communities, economies, and cultures.

Each action we delay, the consequences multiply.

What gives me hope is people. Young people who refuse to accept this as inevitable. 

I’ve seen firsthand the transformative potential of innovation and entrepreneurship. From renewable energy breakthroughs to AI-driven climate solutions, there is no shortage of ideas that can help us address this crisis. What we lack is the urgency to implement them at scale. 

The reality of 2024 demands that we focus our energy, resources, and creativity on preserving the home we have.

I remain hopeful in the emotion, humanity has survived many odds.

And for many retailers, the season of gifting is make-or-break - the season that determines how the year ends. From Black Friday to Christmas and ending with New Year's, this is the time for retailers to maximize record sales. 

For the rest of us? The stress over buying and receiving holiday gifts brings different pressures. Christmas is supposed to be the time for family, togetherness, and giving to the less fortunate, but most of it has morphed into a mad rush to malls, to-do lists, and unwanted spending. 

Stats back this up:
▶️ In the US, holiday sales exceeded $964 billion last year.
▶️ November and December account for 18.4% of all retail sales in the US.
▶️ Therapists also document a rise in anxiety and depression during the holiday season as financial stressors mount, along with loneliness. 

How did we get here? When I think of Christmas, I think about the balance of giving and receiving. Giving was tied to thoughtfulness - whether it was useful handmade things or just time spent together. Now, gifting feels like an obligation rather than an expression of connection.

For a few decades now, I have experimented with growing the fruits and vegetables we eat at home. 

So naturally, that has also led to a deeper study of where food comes from, carbon emissions, and food wastage. 

Just in my grandparent's generation, they ate what was available locally, and with a far wider diversity in their palate. They foraged far more. We have lost the knowledge of the vast edible plants that are abundant. 

One of my favorite dals uses the tender shoot of a tamarind tree, a seasonal abundant resource with high nutritional value.

What is the future of farming? 

Farming techniques need to service a very different population density. We have to find more ways to grow our meals locally, using renewable energy, and consuming fewer resources.

I am sure all this sounds idealistic! Traditional agriculture has many limitations in serving the global population. 

The debate on Delhi pollution and Punjab burning the crops is an example of the ying-yang of modern farming. The long-term health costs of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides are a vicious cycle. We need to eat, but our food today is like slow poison.  

Add this to the destruction of large areas of land and destruction of biodiversity and virgin forests is an environmental disaster. 

Can we grow our food even in urban areas, without harming the planet? Vertical farming offers that solution, especially if it is powered by green renewable energy.

It involves growing crops indoors in stacked layers, often in controlled environments that rely on hydroponics, LED lighting, and climate control. 

By taking agriculture indoors, vertical farms can reduce land use by up to 70% compared to traditional farming.

By powering these farms entirely with renewables, their carbon footprint can drop to near zero.

Dubai is aiming to supply 10% of its fresh produce locally through vertical farms in the future. 

Also, unlike traditional agriculture, which accounts for around 70% of global freshwater use, vertical farming can reduce water usage by up to 90% thanks to recirculating systems. 

Very importantly — the tightly controlled environment drastically reduces the need for pesticides and herbicides, making the food safer and cleaner.

They can be established in densely populated areas, creating local jobs, and helping to build resilient food networks. 

The world’s food system changes completely when food can be cultivated anywhere it is needed—be it a skyscraper in Mumbai or a storage unit in Okhla.

This future of farming is something I am intrigued by. What about you?

When I read about Rukhmabai, I was stuck with the thought, “Where does this courage come from?"

Born in 1864, 𝐑𝐮𝐤𝐡𝐦𝐚𝐛𝐚𝐢 𝐑𝐚𝐮𝐭 was married off at just 11, as was the norm then. 11 is a child with no voice.

Soon, her husband accumulated debts, wanted the property her family had set aside for her — but had no serious life aspirations and refused to study. 

Though unusual at that time, Rukhmabai had access to books and studies at home on various subjects, and she was exposed to ideas of social reformers. She refused to go to her husband's home. 

Her refusal to comply with her husband's demands led to his filing a case seeking ‘restitution of conjugal rights’. 

Thus started the landmark legal battle: The Rukhmabai vs. Dadaji Acharya case. 

It received widespread attention and much public discussion. A judge ordered Rukhmabai to "go live with her husband or face six months of imprisonment." Rukhmabai responded that she would rather face imprisonment than obey the verdict. This resulted in further upheaval and social debate. Balagangadar Tilak, a respected reformer who was still a product of his times, wrote that Rukhmabai's defiance was the result of an English education, and declared that Hinduism was in danger.

Eventually she prevailed and the marriage was dissolved. And there was further change is law on ‘age of consent’ from 10 to 12 years.

What is even more remarkable, she pursued her passion for education. In a time when women’s education, especially in the sciences, was a rarity, Rukhmabai boldly decided to pursue medical studies in London. 

Imagine the courage — faced public ridicule, shunned by respectable society, and took the decision to step into a male-dominated profession halfway around the world at a time like that!

Rukhmabai returned to India in 1893 as a fully qualified physician. She served as the Chief of Women’s Hospital in Surat for 35 years, dedicating her life to improving women's health — a field that had been largely neglected in colonial India.

She questioned what society told her she could and couldn’t be!

Today, her legacy lives on in each of us as we breeze through the doors she so courageously opened.

Good mentors are hard to come by.

And being a mentor to someone? It is even more difficult. 

Whenever someone wants advice, my first instinct is to decline. Most often people want affirmation, not your unbiased opinion. Or they want easy solutions, not the hard work to discover solutions. 

Before you seek a mentor, create clarity in what you are seeking. Are you looking for someone to be a sounding board, or challenge you, or the domain’s depth to offer a deep perspective? 

A mentor and mentee must be truly willing to invest time to iterate the problems and possible solutions through active listening. 

Back in the day, I thought the best help was direct help. If someone came to me with a problem, I’d try to fix it. The logic seemed simple: problem, solution, done. Except, what I would do is not always what ‘they’ should do. Giving advice on limited data is always dangerous. 

Real learning happens when you arrive at an understanding by yourself. And a mentor can probe you and take you into tunnel conversations that might open new channels of thinking.

I’ve learned more from listening to people work through their thoughts than I ever did from trying to dictate solutions. It’s humbling and inspiring to witness someone’s journey toward understanding.

That said, guiding with questions requires patience. 

It’s hard to be in that space of not knowing. It can be transformative to sit with that discomfort, to push through it, and come out stronger on the other side.

A mentor should spark deep thinking, challenge assumptions, and help you grow.

The everyday world is a swirl of patterns. 

We are surrounded by its dance, and we are oblivious to its beauty. 

Books neatly arranged on a shelf, the symmetry of a spiderweb, or how bathroom tiles fit together, the leaves on a tree, the spines on the leaf, a bird formation in the sky — it’s oddly satisfying to our subconscious senses even if we don't actively pay attention to patterns. 

It's in our nature to seek order and be disturbed by unexpected chaos! Patterns are geometry in motion.

And 𝐭𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬, with their intricate patterns and perfect fits, are a prime example of this.

A tessellation is a pattern created by repeating a single shape, over and over again without any gaps or overlaps.

And have been with us for centuries. 

The breathtaking Alhambra Palace in Spain. Its walls are adorned with intricate patterns that repeat endlessly, a tribute to Islamic art's mastery of geometry. 

Every star, every polygon, and every interlacing design is an example of symmetry and precision.

Irregular shapes can tessellate too — if the angles and edges align just right. 

The hexagonal structure of a honeycomb is a perfect example of a natural tessellation. Bees instinctively know how to pack their cells efficiently, maximizing space and minimizing material usage.

You’ll also see tessellations in cracked dry earth, turtle shells, and even pineapple skins. 
And the reason is still the same: minimal resources to cover maximum space.

In architecture, they have practical and decorative purposes. Louvre Abu Dhabi and the roof of the British Museum’s Great Court use tessellations to dazzle the eye and distribute weight evenly, ensuring strength and stability.

In manufacturing, they help minimize material waste, from fabric cuts in fashion design to steel plates in construction.

I can go on and on with the examples.

But the thing to note is even in a chaotic world, there’s room for order and precision. 

Tessellations are a visual representation of how small pieces, when arranged thoughtfully, can create something stunningly cohesive.

Now, please walk around for a minute and comment on what is a pattern you noticed around you. 

Or is there a tessellation in your journeys that captured your imagination?

When I look back on my life, I see that crisis has been a constant companion. 

Not in a bad way — I have realized through all these 60 years that crisis has been a companion for my betterment. A companion who has been frowned upon, reviled, and even rejected! But one who has taught me so much.

I remember way back when I was in the 7th standard, I worried I didn't do well in one paper. The fear of failing the exam was daunting. Panicky, I took all the money from my piggy bank to the temple and offered it all to God, begging that I don't fail. I didn't fail. But I have come far from my early crisis management strategy — hopelessness, delusional thinking, desperation, and wishful praying. ;-) 

Over the years, I have found that we often run from a crisis — who among us wants to embrace a crisis, after all? But it arrives nonetheless uninvited, and we refuse to acknowledge it or face it. As Yoda said, "Train yourself to let go of everything you fear to lose." Name your fear, confront it head-on, and watch it lose its power.

For example, when I started my first company, concerned friends would ask, "How are you making this leap?" But it wasn't about leaping into the abyss, free-falling. When I looked right down at it, fear had a face, and as I stared it down, it lost its hold. I realized that the worst that could happen was I might fail to create a business model or lose my savings. And if that did happen, I knew how to get back on my feet again. I experienced an accelerating freedom to pursue without fear. 

Crisis induces fear. And fear can make us behave in illogical ways or paralyze our judgment. But when we do come through the crisis, we develop newer perspectives and skills and open opportunities for ourselves.

Perhaps, it's why I think Jensen Huang, CEO of Nvdia, had it right when he said, "I wish upon you ample doses of pain and suffering." Why? Because resilience matters. And a good crisis is a masterclass in resilience.

𝐇𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐫𝐞 5 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬 𝐈 𝐮𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐧𝐚𝐯𝐢𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐜𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐬:
▶️ I'd step back if I am overwhelmed. I go for a walk and give the situation time to simmer down and get a fresh perspective. 
▶️ Never rush solutions. Don't try to find solutions when you aren't in the right frame of mind.
▶️ Be open to new perspectives.
▶️ Focus on solutions, reach for courage, and face down fear.
▶️ Embrace crisis as an opportunity for growth.

And that's it, really. In 60 years, crises have been a constant companion, yes. But one I have learned much from.

Working hours, working age, minimum wage, and many other workforce considerations shift and evolve to fit the times and social sentiments.

Before the Industrial Revolution, children labored along with their families. And in a pooled effort, there was no question of protecting minimum wage. 

However, this trend continued during the Industrial Revolution. It became exploitative and soul-crushing versus uplifting in the cause of a family laboring together. Hence laws governing legal age, safety, minimum wage, etc came into being.

With the rise of the gig economy, moonlighting, hybrid work models, and more — employee needs have shifted.

How do we curate concrete benefits that genuinely resonate with today’s and tomorrow’s workforce?

Bonuses, vouchers, overtime pay, free food, etc., are an old thing. Today’s employees expect workplaces to share their values and causes, champion their personal constraints, and offer better professional growth.

Benefits must align with their evolving values, life stages, and priorities. Once considered an optional add-on, mental health resources are now a core expectation.

For instance, recognizing the role of fathers in caregiving, many companies now offer extended paternity leave. And caregiving benefits include elder care and flexible pet care options. 

Did you know Spotify offers six months of parental leave and covers costs for fertility assistance, including egg freezing?

Then, Salesforce’s Wellness Reimbursement Program offers employees up to $1,000 annually for fitness classes, mental health services, nutrition consultations and more.  

PwC has implemented an interesting student loan repayment program: It contributes $1,200 annually toward employees’ student loans. This is a game-changer for younger employees burdened by debt.

I am sure many more organizations are offering customised benefits and refreshing them every few years.

According to a recent LinkedIn Workplace Report, over 60% of employees prioritize flexibility and work-life balance when deciding whether to join or stay with a company. Similarly, SHRM data reveals that organizations offering personalized benefits experience 41% higher retention rates than those sticking to conventional models.

The future workplace will thrive on customization, inclusivity, and addressing needs across the employee's life stage.

We all have tubes of this at home. 

School projects; fixing a glass bowl; repairing shoes; restoring wooden cabinets — what’s the common link between these everyday tasks?

𝐅𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐜𝐨𝐥!

This iconic Indian brand has become synonymous with quick-fix for a myriad of projects.

For over six decades, Fevicol has held the top spot in India's adhesive market. 

Its journey began in 1959 when Balvant Parekh, an entrepreneur, saw a gap in the market. Traditional glues (animal-based), were messy and inconvenient. 

Unlike other adhesives primarily sold for professional use, Fevicol targeted both professionals and everyday consumers. 

The iconic 30-gram collapsible tube, launched in 1970, became a staple in every Indian household, from fixing broken toys to making school projects.

But what really made them stand apart? Apart from a good product, their clever marketing campaigns! Creative and quirky — they’ve been able to connect and stay relevant with customers.

Over the years, Fevicol has delivered some of India’s most iconic and memorable ads. Witty jingles, relatable scenarios, and a focus on the product's strength resonated with audiences across generations.

“Fevicol ka majboot jodo hai, tootega nahi”

Likewise rajkumar hirani created their famous ad Dum Laga ke Haisha.

Another ridiculous (and effective) ad I remember is the egg ad, the chef struggling to break an egg, because the hen ate Fevicol! If you can remember an ad decades later, you must appreciate the marketing genius.

Fast-forward to today, Fevicol is worth over ₹145,000 crore and commands more than 70% of India’s adhesive market.

Its product line has expanded, catering to various needs- heavy-duty furniture bonding, water-resistant adhesives, and even solutions for crafting.

In a way, Fevicol represents what all great brands should - product resilience, building business that lasts, and creating relatable bonds with customers!

It has truly stuck around (pun intended), earning a permanent place in Indian hearts and homes.

The older I get, the more aware I have become of the miracle of my body. 

So often, we take our body for granted and don't appreciate the daily miracles it performs. Instead of taking care of our health, we neglect and abuse that miracle with wacky food choices, lack of proper sleep, and inadequate movement. 

When we realize what we are doing, in our bid to get it right, we also make health overly complicated. 

Simple everyday habits can make our lives healthier. These are 10 habits that I think are worth practicing in a world where we have so many conveniences leading to unhealthy habits and lifestyles. 

▶️ 𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐲𝐞𝐫: I remember that, as children, we used to eat food only after praying. Taking a moment for prayer and gratitude shifts our relationship with food. 
 
▶️ 𝐌𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐟𝐮𝐥 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐦𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: Keep the phone and TV away from the eating area. Make mealtimes all about just the food, eating, and mindful conversation. It helps you with portion control and enjoyment. Screens make the meal a chore versus a joyful activity that nourishes us. 

▶️ 𝐁𝐞𝐝𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐬: Take 20 minutes to just wind down with a book (preferably not an e-book) as a calming practice. Alternatively, try meditating for 10 minutes to unclog the day's stressors. This makes going to bed an experience, not just an end to the day.
  
▶️ 𝐌𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐲: Exercise doesn't have to be complicated. Schedule a timer for movement breaks. Small bouts of activity throughout are more important than 100 squats in the gym once a week.  

▶️ 𝐒𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐬𝐨𝐜𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐧𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬: Being isolated and comfortable in our digital lives can lead to more loneliness. Meet a friend. Plan a coffee together. Real conversations can benefit our health more than endless scrolling. 

▶️ 𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐝 𝐣𝐨𝐲 𝐢𝐧 𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐭𝐥𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬: Find small moments of joy throughout the day. A hobby you love, a song that brings a smile to your face, or even a few moments of reflection. 

▶️ 𝐑𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐥𝐚𝐫 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡 𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐜𝐤-𝐮𝐩𝐬: An annual blood test or a regular full-fledged health check can prevent problems before they get too big.  

▶️ 𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐞 𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞: Take a few minutes to appreciate something small each day. Maybe, that cup of tea your partner handed you. A nice walk. A friend's birthday. Gratitude shifts your mind to looking at the larger perspective.  

▶️ 𝐇𝐲𝐝𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐝𝐟𝐮𝐥𝐥𝐲: Water is the most underrated health hack. Staying hydrated all day helps everything from focus to skin to hunger. 

▶️ 𝐃𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐤 𝐢𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: If you drink at all, drink in moderation and be conscious of your weekly intake. Drinking is not to drown reality.

These are my favorite health tips. What are yours? What can you add to the list?

interesting musings for fintech & crypto.

in the past year i have encountered a handful of startups raising an equity round where the ceo/founder did not plan, wanted or believed in the benefits of a proper board.

they viewed a board solely as a net/net negative that would slow them down. they did not understand the benefits nor did they understand the associated risks of not having a proper governance.

further, i was told by these founders that the other investors willing to invest (these were funds, but not necessarily traditional venture funds) did not require proper governance and boards.

i know of at least 3 startups, that for this description, which ended up closing a round. 

given market exuberance, these rounds were closed at relatively high valuations with high amounts raised.

all between post seed and pre A rounds.

although i am perfectly willing to concede that a founder and founding team can be successful without proper governance, i do believe such path leads to higher risks and unintended consequences.

additionally, and this might be anecdotal, in all cases, while performing due diligence on these startups i found out that the other investors were not even bothering interviewing the entire teams. for such early stage investments that surprised me.

i can only imagine the type of shareholder agreement and investor rights needed when no board is considered. or maybe those investors do not even bother about that, which makes me question their sanity.

one founder even told me that by asking for a board I showed him I did not trust him enough, compared to other investors who did not require one. that left me speechless indeed. 

i have come up with 2 explanations first, given the amount of capital available and the proliferation of new funds in the market, founders can entertain offers from investors with risk profiles markedly divergent from traditional norms.

second, investments in crypto protocols have shown one can raise money in a non traditional way. this might indirectly impact traditional equity raises? 

i am opened to other explanations.

If you talk to recruiters or HR reps these days, you're sure to hear a lot about the "war for talent." What often gets less attention is what that means for workers.
Last week, I visited the headquarters of Dell Technologies in Texas, where I met Kate Cosway, a woman with a master's degree in chemical engineering who had been unable to get a job because of her autism -- until this year, when she was hired through a new program for people on the autism spectrum. I met a software engineer who had taken two years off when she had children, then struggled to get back to work -- until Dell hired her through a new "Career Restart" program. And I stopped by Austin Community College, where employers were practically fighting over themselves to hire students -- and were willing to overlook barriers like inexperience or criminal records that might have been an issue in past years.
There's been lots of talk recently (from me, among others) about whether the U.S. economy is headed for a recession. But it's worth remembering why it's so important to keep the expansion going as long as possible: The strong job market is creating opportunities for people who were left behind early in the recovery.

As I wrote in today's New York Times, the revision doesn't change the big picture: The labor market is in good shape. But 500,000 jobs is a lot of jobs! Certainly enough to deserve attention. Plus, as LinkedIn Chief Economist Guy Berger, Ph.D. told me, big data revisions can be a sign that the economy is at a turning point -- a troubling thought given the other economic warning signs out there right now. (Still, Dr. Berger doesn't see evidence of a recession just yet.)

If you've tried to buy a house lately, you might have found yourself running up against some unexpected competition: investors.
Time was, the single-family housing market was pretty much the sole province of individual owners, or maybe a few small-time partnerships. But after the housing bubble burst, big institutional investors swooped in to buy up millions of houses for pennies on the dollar. And to almost everyone's surprise, they've kept buying even as prices have rebounded. One in five starter homes sold in the U.S. last year were bought by investors. In some markets, it was closer to half.
All those investors mean more competition for ordinary buyers, at a time when affordability is already a huge challenge in many cities. But it's a complicated story -- investors are also helping to rehab homes that were abandoned in the foreclosure crisis.
In today's The New York Times, Conor Dougherty and I explore this trend through one home in Atlanta, which was sold three times in less than a year -- and nearly quadrupled in price. Don't miss the drone footage!

Ben Casselman's post 6yr ago:
We learned two things from this morning's G.D.P. report:
1. The economy is slowing;
2. But it's not falling off a cliff.

That might sound like damning with faint praise. But after a disastrous retail sales report earlier this month, there were a lot of economists who thought growth fell below 2 percent at the end of the year. Compared to that, 2.6 percent looks pretty good.

That said, there are good reasons to think growth will continue to slow from here. The shutdown, for one, which came too late to matter much to Q4 but could be a big drag in Q1. Tax cuts and government spending increases helped boost growth last year, but those effects are now fading. And (to get a bit in the weeds for a second) Thursday's figures were helped by a build-up of inventories, which will probably reverse in the first quarter of this year.

So President Trump can cheer an economy that (at least by one measure) met his 3 percent target for 2018, but he's not likely to get a repeat performance in 2019. The big question now is whether that mild slowdown worsens into an outright recession. That's not the most likely scenario, but it's certainly a possibility, especially if global growth continues to cool or the trade war heats up. 

Stay tuned.

For all of the glow that surrounds manufacturing jobs in political rhetoric, there is nothing inherently special about them. Some pay well; others don’t. They are not immune from the forces that have led to slow wage growth in other sectors of the economy. When politicians pledge to protect manufacturing jobs, they really mean a certain kind of job: well-paid, long-lasting, with opportunities for advancement. Those aren’t qualities associated with working on a factory floor; they’re qualities associated with being a member of a union.

Based on media depictions, you'd think that "college" in America mostly means four years spent on a leafy suburban campus, hitting frat parties and studying philosophy. The reality is far different. Most U.S. students don't fit the traditional profile: They are older, or attend part-time, or go to community college. Most don't live on campus. And more than 75% of undergrads attend schools that accept more than half their applicants. Yet the media writes incessantly about college admissions while largely ignoring issues that affect the majority.

BMW's 3 Series sedans bound for the United States are made by a German company in Mexico, hence they are ineligible for special deals with the Trump administration. 

They used to carry a 2.5% tax coming into the US but under the current tariffs, it's now 27.5%. Which takes a base model with a $47,000 sticker and makes it closer to $60,000. BMW recently guided to a billion dollars in cost this year as a result, borne by the company itself as opposed to consumers or dealerships. They'll absorb this extra cost until May 1st. Then what? 

This is obviously unsustainable.

Set aside an hour to listen to Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent on the All In Podcast. Try to listen objectively as he lays out the reasoning behind the new economic policies and objectives. 

He genuinely wants to remove the distortions of lobbying and government overspending to improve the possibilities for middle class employment in the private sector. 

In the Bessent worldview, people see the cuts to spending and federal employment immediately but it will take a while before they feel the benefits. He sees the realignment of global trade as working hand-in-glove with deregulation to make it easier to build products and hire people within the United States. He’s trying to navigate through the outrage (and short-term economic consequences) until he gets to the other side. 

You may not agree with him about whether or not it’s going to work. But hearing the rationale without the lens of Fox News or the New York Times is useful if you’re trying to understand it all.

Advisors: Using this quiet moment between T3 Technology Tools for Today and Future Proof Citywide to let you in on a little secret with massive implications for your business. No one else will ever tell you this stuff, but I got you -

There are only two questions you need to ask before implementing a startup's software in your practice:

1. Is the company well-capitalized and financially able to execute its roadmap?

2. Do the custodians have anything to lose by ripping out the cord that connects its API?

If the answer to either of these questions is "No" then that's that. Nothing else matters.

Don't worry about demos, don't worry about slides. Everybody's got a dope demo. All the slides are pretty.

Question 1:

Ask the founder how much they've raised and from whom. The average fintech software engineer in Manhattan makes $162,000, according to ZipRecruiter. So figure the national average outside of NYC, SF and LA is more like $115,000 (AVERAGE, RELAX!). Is the dollar amount the founder tells you they've raised sufficient to maintain four or five of those salaries plus pay themselves for the next 12 months? If not, are they raising right now? Remember, they're going to have to add some salary + bonus salespeople too. No funding, no onboarding, that's my rule.

They've got money? Good. First hurdle cleared.

Then I want you to call the highest ranking person at Fidelity and Schwab you have access to and repeat after me: 

"How many firms on your platform are using ____ and would they be upset if you cut the API?" 

Do this on Zoom, not over the phone, so you can look the person in the eye.

They will deflect and say "There's ABSOLUTELY no plans to sever that connection at the moment, don't be silly" because that's their job (or maybe they don't know), so I want you pay attention not just to the words but to the facial expression and the degree of incredulity at the question. If they're thinking "NO WAY WOULD WE EVER CUT OUT ADDEPAR! OH MY GOD CAN YOU IMAGINE THE UPROAR!" it will show up in the way they respond. Watch whether or not their eyes look up and to the right - this is what it looks like when someone is subconsciously attempting to access the creative side of the brain aka the Lie Factory. 

You can have the best wealthtech software product ever devised in the history of the RIA industry. You win all the awards, speak on all the stages, make all the lists. But if the custodians don't want to maintain the API or, worse, see you as competition for some shit they're trying to build in-house - you're dead. Especially if there's no revenue attached to it. No revenue means no rabbi inside the building sticking up for you. 

Your job as a prospective purchaser of this software is to make sure your most important provider - the brokerage custodian - has something to lose by kicking it out.

Once satisfied on the answers to these two questions, you have my permission to proceed with the experiment. Hope this helps.

Bill Ackman is proposing a transaction whereby he raises his equity stake in Howard Hughes Corp, a publicly-traded real estate holding company, to 48% at a big premium to today's price. The board and executives continue to run the real estate company while he uses the stock as a vehicle to make additional public and private investments like his own version of Berkshire Hathaway. 

For his investment services, the company pays him a 1.5% annual management fee on the company's market capitalization. This would be roughly $55 million this year based on the current valuation but would of course be worth much more if Bill can increase the company's stock price. 

William D. Cohan has a full write-up for Puck here: 

https://lnkd.in/gdMC9Vtr

My comment is that it's a cool idea and if you're a fan of Bill Ackman, probably the best version of getting some of your capital under the management of Pershing Square. He's tried lots of other ways to make his investment ideas available to investors not in his hedge fund but they haven't been viable / marketable. 

One very big problem with the structure, however, if Berkshire Hathaway 2.0 is the goal, is that the not-so-hidden secret to Berkshire's success is that it's built around a massive insurance company. This means the money Warren Buffett gets to invest comes in regardless of market conditions because it's people making insurance payments. This is why he's had steady, permanent capital to invest even during market crashes when traditional asset managers have seen big outflows and investors walking away. 

I'm not certain this can replicated by the income from commercial real estate leases. It will certainly make it impossible for Howard Hughes to attain Berkshire's Triple-A rated credit status. You’re going to be hearing a lot about something called DeepSeek R1 this weekend because it represents a breakthrough that is shaking the AI research community around the world. 

I’m not a scientist, but here’s what I think is important about it: 

During the few hours where TikTok was offline in the United States, a small startup based in Hangzhou released a paper on their own LLM called DeepSeek and they open-sourced the code. They showed it outperforming OpenAI’s 4o model - thought to be the cutting edge - along multiple parameters like reasoning, coding, mathematical problem-solving, etc. 

Tech people were shocked considering how far behind China’s companies were thought to have been.  

What’s remarkable is that this tiny startup was able to beat ChatGPT and Claude Sonnet with only $6 million of spend on chips and compute. 

For comparison, Meta and Alphabet are paying $6 million salaries to individual AI engineers and hiring them around the clock. They’re spending billions on chips and power consumption. The DeepSeek LLM was trained with just 2000 Nvidia GPUs while Llama and Gemini required more like 16,000 GPUs. 

There are three aspects to DeepSeek that sets it apart from other LLMs worth understanding. 

1. Chain of Thought 

DeepSeek uses “Chain of Thought” as its method of inference. The training doesn’t ask it a question and then just hand it the right answer. The model has to “show its work” and reason its way to the right answer out loud. Which means if something goes wrong along the way, the user can pinpoint it by looking at the chain. Many LLM outputs are a black box - the engineers can’t even tell you how they arrive at the answers they give sometimes. 

2. Reinforcement Learning

Think of a baby learning to walk, steadying itself by holding onto furniture to “train” its own muscles and joints. You can’t explain how to walk to a baby because babies don’t understand explanations. DeepSeek continually trains itself through reinforcement learning by earning “rewards” as opposed to being fed the correct responses.  

3. Distillation 

One more thing that makes this so remarkable - the cost advantage is enormous. Using a technique called “distillation”, a large LLM can teach a smaller LLM what it needs to know to solve problems and the smaller LLM goes on to outperform at these tasks despite using a fraction of the parameters its “teacher” LLM required to teach it. Inferencing with 7 billion parameters vs 700 billion parameters in a model can reduce the compute to a fraction of what is now the standard cost for AI use. 

My big takeaway: If a few researchers with a $6 million budget and a couple thousand GPUs can send trillion-dollar companies into a panic, the AI Era is going to be even wilder and unpredictable than we can possibly know. The potential for upsets and left turns should not be underestimated. 

Whatever you feel certain about today may seem incredibly foolish tomorrow.

Rejection 101: 

Early Career

Smile and say thank you. The No’s are doing more for you than the Yes’s will. You are learning. A mental list of what works, what doesn’t and why. If what you were trying to do were easy, it would have no value. Anyone could do it. Embrace the walls you face for someday you’ll be on the other side and those walls will be your protection, someone else’s obstacle. 

Mid Career

You should be outwardly zen about the No’s and No Thank You’s but inside I want you to be seething. Lathered up with rage. Either you’re selling the wrong thing (so stop and make a change) or you’re selling the right thing but incorrectly. Figure it out or you’re on a treadmill forever. A fifty year old worried about quotas and layoffs. Focus on making it really hard for people to choose something else over whatever you’re offering. Then focus on how you convey that to others. Become the default option. The easy button. 

Late Career

Hopefully, you’ve built something so undeniably good and a platform so powerful that only an idiot would say No. And you’re good with that because you have no time for idiots. The No’s should be less impactful for you individually. “Oh well.” People who reject you should be off the list forever. “Dead to me” I like to say (jokingly) or “Okay, good luck out there.” You’re done asking people twice. Let them regret having missed the chance to have you in their service. 

Final Stage 

You’re now the one doing the rejecting. Saying No to the stuff you don’t need. Being selfish with your time because it’s running out. The shoe is on the other foot. The devil, as always, is in the details and the data. And science experiments using rats. Here’s what I mean 👇

In March of 2020, the PYMNTS Intelligence team began to benchmark the paycheck-to-paycheck status of Americans as part of our monthly consumer studies related to COVID, the digital shift and how people spent and saved their money.
 
5 years later, 67% of Americans consumers live paycheck-to-paycheck, and for those who haven’t been keeping up on our studies, the picture of these consumers is no less murky. That’s probably because these consumers are extremely nuanced.  It’s not about being rich, it’s not about being poor, and paycheck-to-paycheck living is a continuum between choice and necessity.
 
There are also two critical income thresholds for the paycheck-to-paycheck consumer, and they span a wide range. The first is $45,000-$49,99; with the second being $125,000-$149,999.
 
So why’s it all matter now? Uncertainty, for one. It might be my word of the year, and it’s underscored by the current Administration’s comments that hint at a likely recession. After all, in order to be a paycheck-to-paycheck consumer, you first need to have a paycheck.

Granted it was the 90's but my at first CPA job I was not allowed to talk to a client for 2 YEARS!   

When I was at PW (yes, I never talk about those first 2 years) I was actually in Tax Tech support and was on the phone thinking on my feet the whole day...the best way to learn how to have conversationsin CUSTOMER SUPPORT roles.

For decades, the CPA profession has focused on technical expertise—compliance, tax, and auditing—leaving a crucial gap: advisory and communication skills.

Here’s why this gap exists:
 ➡️ Fear of relationship transfer: Partners guarded client relationships, afraid clients would leave with staff who moved on.
 ➡️ No financial incentive: Unlike wealth management, where mentorship often comes with financial rewards, CPA firms lacked a structure to incentivize teaching soft skills.
 ➡️ Traditional focus: Historically, CPAs trained for technical mastery, with little emphasis on the human side of client relationships.
 ➡️ Generational gaps: Junior CPAs often weren’t given the confidence or tools to have impactful client conversations.


But here’s the truth: as tech evolves and automates compliance tasks, advisory is the future. And with more tech, we need to become more human—not less.

In 1834, the Cambridge don William Whewell wrote a complimentary article about Mary Somerville, a Scottish researcher whose erudite books brought together previously disparate fields of mathematics, astronomy, geology, chemistry, and physics so clearly that the texts became the backbone of Cambridge University’s first science curriculum. He called Somerville a scientist, in part because “man of science” seemed inappropriate for a woman, but more significantly because Somerville’s work was interdisciplinary. She was no mere astronomer, physicist, or chemist, but a visionary thinker who articulated the connections among the various branches of inquiry. 

According to Somerville’s biographer Kathryn Neeley, Whewell’s coinage of the word  “scientist” was not meant to be merely a gender-neutral neutral term. Whewell wanted a word that actively celebrated “the peculiar illumination of the female mind”: the ability to synthesize separate fields into a single discipline.” 

In suggesting the term “scientist,” he emphasized its similarity to how the word “artist” is formed. Indeed, he had recognized in Somerville that singular creative genius of drawing connections between the seemingly disconnected, which is itself an artistic achievement.

Are you still at this (financial education)?...someone asked yesterday.

Yes I am. 'Cos I am still learning. 'Cos there is still work to be done.

The journey started decades ago...

I first started working on investor education in 1999 as a twenty-something year old working at an influential investment research firm in Australia. We were trying to help investors select the appropriate asset allocation, mutual funds and stocks within their retirement accounts - given that they were about to get that choice in the middle of a raging bull market. We didn’t quite make it to them - the sharemarket bubble burst, they lost money in their retirement accounts and I lost money on my employers' stock. 

Leading up to the 2008 bull market, I tried to revive the idea with my now institutional consulting employer. I now had remit over Asia Pacific..I was excited when the Indian regulators drafted a comprehensive plan on financial education alongside the launch of the New Pension System. The market crashed again, the government changed, the idea was put on the back burner again. 

I quit corporate life eventually.

I tried again in 2012 this time as a content startup that would provide continuing professional development to wealth managers and short animated videos to their investors at just-in-time at point-of-sale. The Indian industry was not interested so I walked away again.

In 2014, I wrote a book, but never sent it to the publisher because a friend’s feedback was that I was trying to go from 0 to 10. I had started with the very basics of personal finance and ended up with very advanced techniques of how to select mutual funds and stocks.

In 2015, I started drip-feeding the chapter summaries as LinkedIn posts. A few of my posts did well - and to my surprise, I found myself on the inaugural global TopVoices list for finance. I got an offer to collaborate on a web-series in which we used humour - the coin-headed Sikka was a proxy for the finance industry that spouted jargon while I tried to communicate the basic premise that finance was common sense. It worked! But then the firm shut down.

Over the next few years, I kept experimenting with formats - short videos, explainer illustrations, podcasts, some with the help of the investor education budgets of mutual funds, but mostly on my own. A few more LinkedIn awards later, just as I was getting ready to pitch for an OTT web series, of course there was a bull market, not just in the stock market but also in the content pushed out by twenty-something ‘finfluencers’. You guessed it - it went on the back burner again.

And now I am launching yet another series : )

Had some interesting follow up conversations with people offline from my recent post on SaaS design/designers/AI.

There seems to be some concept that only "designers" can "design". Design is not some intrinsic set of capabilities born to a select group of chosen people. Like anything, it's a skill that you can get better at. And the great thing about it is that there are tons of practical guides out there to help product managers and engineers design well. I really like the Refactoring UI book by the Tailwind people. It's full of lovely practical tidbits.

My thinking on having such defined roles about what a PM does v. a designer v. an engineer has changed dramatically over the past few years. Everything is fluid and these strict rules about what person X with title Y should do feels silly to me. All that to say --> go forth and build, whatever your title is.

Last week, I was texting with a friend who runs growth and product at a SaaS healtech startup. We were chatting about his open roles - two engineers. I asked him about designers and his comment was “we don’t need them”.

After my recent post about AI/PMs (with plenty of heated debates in the comments 🍿), this got me thinking about the evolution of the design role along the same lines as Product Management.

I think people don't want to admit this out loud but 99% of SaaS products don't need custom designs. They need clean, functional interfaces that solve real problems.

I'm not talking about brand/graphic design or illustrations - that's a different game. Instead, I'm talking about the day-to-day UX work that powers most SaaS products. And here's the reality: the tools that exist today have commoditised good design.

shadcn/ui: The new king of component libraries. Never heard of it? It's basically LEGO for web apps - gorgeous, accessible components that just work. Teams like Vercel and Stripe are already using these patterns.

Untitled UI: The "premium template" that somehow powers half the SaaS products you use (yes, even the ones that raised millions). It's not cheap, but it's cheaper than a designer.

TailwindUI/DaisyUI: The "I need it done yesterday" solution that still looks professional. Thousands of components and ready to go out of the box.

These aren't just templates - they're battle-tested UX patterns that work. And AI is getting scary good at mixing and matching these components into coherent interfaces.

"But AI can't understand user needs!" Okay, fine. But neither can designers who are debating corner radius in Figma comments and not talking to paying users every day.

The hard truth about AI and UX design:
- AI will generate your layouts
- AI will implement your components
- AI will handle responsive design
- AI will maintain visual consistency

But here's what AI can't do (yet):
- Read between the lines of real user feedback (users say they want dark mode, but they really want to feel like power users)
- Balance stakeholder politics (the CEO's pet feature conflicts with what users actually need)
- Understand cultural nuances that affect user behavior (why a design pattern that works in the US flops in China)
- Identify when to break design rules (know when consistency should take a backseat to solving a unique problem)

Sound familiar? It should. Just like with PMs, the mediocre will be automated away. And maybe that's not a bad thing. I don’t think SaaS users care if your design is "unique." They care if it works. A clean, standard interface that solves their problem will beat an "innovative, award-winning design" that doesn't do what they need every single time.

The greatest risk isn't AI. It's being a pixel-pusher in a world that needs problem solvers.

Meet the velvet ant.

It invades another insect's nest, where they've laid their young and lays its own egg. The egg develops quickly and then eats the young insects from the nest while they're still in the larval stage. Then it goes, leaving behind nothing of value.

Meet its digital equivalent: the domain name squatter (Domainus Squatterus).
These parasites crawl the web looking for expiring domains or any domain that hasn't been taken yet, snatch them up, and park them on the cheapest possible hosting showing nothing but automated ads. They contribute zero value. Their sole purpose? Waiting to extort money from legitimate businesses who actually want to build products and create value with a legitimately named domain. In case you couldn't guess, this post was prompted by exactly my experience this morning for the next new product I'm working on.

Just as the velvet ant is falsely named (it's a wasp, not an ant), these squatters often hide behind shell companies and anonymous registrations. They're not 'domain investors' or 'digital real estate specialists' - they're parasites who do nothing but exploit.

At least the velvet ant follows natural instinct. The domain name squatter has no excuse.

2025 feels like I'm living in the future. 

Growing up in the (19)80's, the concept of living in 2025 literally felt like Star Trek even though I knew logically that it was only 40ish years. But now that we're actually here and I'm reflecting, I'm blown away by the technological advancements that I've seen come to life. They might seem commonplace to us now. Yet, I can't help but think of the Arthur C. Clark quote: “Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.”

Here are three things that seem so everyday now but as a child, I wouldn't have imagined that they would be.

1. Mobile 📱 
My family was pretty into tech growing up. We saved up to buy new computers and we had internet access. My dad even had a "mobile" phone in what seemed like a suitcase. To now carry around a device that can perform incredibly complex tasks and instantly connect with anyone worldwide feels magical. The computing power in our pockets exceeds what sent humans to the moon, and we can use it to scroll through cat videos and order pizza!

2. Self-driving cars 🚗
When I was a kid, KITT from Knight Rider was pure science fiction. I even have a photo of myself sitting in the car at a theme park. A car that could drive itself seemed as far-fetched as teleportation. Yet here we are, with vehicles that can navigate complex traffic situations, park themselves, and even summon themselves from parking spots. While we're not quite at the level of KITT's witty banter, the fact that I can take my hands off the wheel on the highway and trust the car to maintain speed and lane position still feels surreal.

3. AI 🤖
This might be the most "magical" of all. Growing up, AI was either the menacing HAL 9000 or the friendly but clearly artificial Johnny 5. The idea that I could have a natural conversation with an AI, ask it to write code, analyse data, or help me write a story would have blown my young mind. Now we casually chat with AI assistants, use them to generate art, and solve complex problems. Even my 5 year old uses ChatGPT to ask questions and make bedtime stories.

What's perhaps most remarkable is how quickly we adapt to these technologies, making the magical seem mundane. Yet when we step back and look through the eyes of our younger selves, it's truly magical. I know that there are also very real and negative consequences of new technologies but I'm fundamentally a tech optimist at heart and I believe that used in the right way, we'll continually advance humanity.

Happy new year! Here's to 2025 and all the years to come.

You don’t have to look far to see headlines about rising inflation and growing economic uncertainty. But as a founder, I think we shouldn’t get too fixated on what’s happening in the outside environment. 

Fundamentally, you need one of two things to be successful as a startup founder. 

👉 Either you’re building a product that will lower costs by increasing efficiencies and improving the level of service offered. 

👉 On the flip side, you might be building a growth product that is going to drive revenue and get you one step closer to profitability. 

Regardless of what’s happening in the outside economic climate, you need to be focused on (at least) one of these two things. 

The only thing that changes in an economic downturn is where you focus your capital and resources. 

If things are going gangbusters, you might have 70% of your roadmap focused on growth and revenue products. On the flip side, if there are choppy waters ahead, you’re likely to put more emphasis on efficiency and cost-reduction products. 

The core building blocks of designing products and building a good company don’t change, your focus simply needs to shift between growth vs. efficiency.

I know how common it is for real estate teams to be using 5+ pieces of software in their agency. 📱

But why? It comes down to this 👉 most pieces of tech only solve one part of the whole experience in real estate. 

One app might be great at leasing while another has specialist tools for maintenance or repairs. 

The reality is that it's incredibly rare to find the perfect tool (a.k.a. The Swiss army knife) in proptech. Instead, these tools are built for specific purposes, rather than being an all-in-one solution. 

There’s another part to the story, which is the level of involvement an agency principal wants to have. I like to think about it in the same way I think about the question: “what am I having for dinner?”

I could decide to run to the grocery store and prepare a home-cooked meal from scratch or I could use a service like Providoor or UberEATS to bring my meal to me. 

I could even hand over the entire experience to a chef and pay a bit more to eat out at a restaurant. 

The same decisions need to be made by real estate agencies. Do you pick a tool that requires a high level of involvement from you, or do you pick a truly all-in-one provider that can deliver a top-notch service using a trusted solution?

I think it all comes back to finding the right solution that can give you a guaranteed level of service the first time, every time.

As a founder of a startup, you’ve got a thousand things on your plate. Tackling immediate deadlines are likely to take priority over long-term tasks, like building relationships with potential investors. 

I’m often asked about when you should start having conversations with investors as a founder. Obviously, the sooner the better. This gives you enough time to really spell out and articulate the vision you have for your company and what you’re working towards.

But your time is a finite resource. Building relationships with hundreds of investors take hours out of your week, and most of these meetings won’t lead to an investment. 

💡 My tip? Focus your time and energy on strategic relationships. 

If you’re launching a product that’s unique and relevant to a specific industry, reach out to strategic investors in that space where you can present a rationale for partnership and investment. It’s not about getting the partnership immediately; that’s unlikely to happen. Rather, it’s about getting in front of people early so that when the need arises, you’ve already established a foundation.

The rest of your time can be spent building relationships with VC firms that might be a good fit for your company. Again, be selective and handpick VCs that have a very real reason to invest in your company (whether that’s because of shared values, their fund’s thesis, or industry). 

Don’t just pick the biggest names. Instead, focus your time on building meaningful relationships with investors who are going to deeply care about what you’re building.

For owners, we needed to make sure this process started early enough to allow for price reviews, changes to rental terms, and even allow for releasing (if the tenant does decide to move on).

This might be a hot take, but here it goes. 👀

Product owners are a role that shouldn’t exist.

In Australia, I’ve seen a number of companies where the product ownership responsibilities and product management responsibilities are split between two different people.

That means one person creates the vision of a product, and the other is on the hook for the execution. 

But in my opinion, you can’t separate those two things. If you don’t have the right vision, you can’t execute it properly. And how can you be expected to execute well when you don’t have ownership of vision? What happens after a product launches? Who’s ultimately responsible for making it successful? A product doesn’t end once it ships - that’s the just the beginning. 

By splitting these functions into two roles there’s no way to tell if you’re building the right thing or how you should adapt and change along the way.

Plus, it’s important to show that you’re building a high-performing team. 🤝

 While I don’t think you need to have a full leadership team built out, you’ll need to show that you’re bringing the right people together and working toward a shared goal. 

At this point, you’ll also be a larger company than in your previous raises. So you need to be showing that you’re growing as a company, and that’s continuing to happen (a.k.a. you can’t be plateauing). 

The other piece to remember is around dilution. At Series A you’ll likely have to give up another 20% of your round. But you can’t keep doing that at every round, so you have to think about what the future looks like. 

After Series A, are you on track to profitability or are you planning for another raise?

Finally, be aware that this round usually takes longer than raising at a Seed stage - so make sure you’re planning ahead and mapping out your runways in advance.
