Most of the time, when we sit down to write, we write with the intention of using the words that we produce. Whether we’re writing an email, a school essay, a business proposal, or a blog post, we’ve got a very specific goal in mind: inform a colleague, impress a teacher, persuade a client, educate a reader.

But what if you wrote without any intention of ever showing your words to the world? What if you wrote simply as a meditative exercise that can help you clear your mind, process your emotions, and tap into your creative potential?

That’s precisely what Julia Cameron recommends. Cameron is a poet, screenwriter, creativity coach, and author of 40 books, including "The Miracle of Morning Pages: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About the Most Important Artist's Way Tool."

In her book, she introduces what she calls “morning pages”, a daily free-writing ritual that can help you sort through tough issues you might be tackling in your personal or professional life. “The morning pages are three pages of longhand writing, strictly stream-of-consciousness.”

Unlike talk therapy, which can also be highly effective at address mental health issues, but which comes with a cost that may not always be completely covered by your insurance provider, morning pages is a simple and completely free exercise that requires no technology beyond a few sheets of paper and a pen or pencil. In fact, Cameron strongly advises against using a computer to write morning pages.

In addition to writing by hand, she also suggests:

Write as soon as you wake.

Cameron recommends writing morning pages as early as possible, soon after you wake-up, and after you’ve had your morning brew. “As a coffee lover myself, I wouldn’t want to get in the way of your favorite pick-me-up.”

Just keep writing.

Write whatever comes to mind, however trivial it might seem. Just keep writing until you’ve filled three 8 1/2 x 11 inch pages, she advises. I try to fill three pages in a blue Moleskin notebook — not exactly the size of paper that Julia recommends. Use whatever size, thickness, or color of paper that feels right for you.

Don’t write to publish.

Don’t write with the expectation that you’ll use the material in a piece that you plan to publish. Write for yourself, and write without the inhibiting editorial voice in your head — the “Censor”, Cameron calls it — that tells you to cut this or that out of your writing.

Don’t show your morning pages to anyone.

Cameron strongly advises to keep your morning pages entirely to yourself: “Nobody is allowed to read your morning pages except you. And you shouldn’t even read them yourself for the first eight weeks or so. Just write three pages…and write three more pages the next day.”

Have you written morning pages, or practiced another similar journaling exercise? Share your experiences in the comments.

📝Writing Tip of the Day: Reliving the Pain

I had the privilege of speaking to Andrea W. about her bestselling medical memoir, "Better Off Bald: A Life in 147 Days." 

It's her story about how she raised her younger sister Adrienne from the age of eight until she died from liver cancer at the age of 15. 

It's a beautiful story and one with a universal message not only for caretakers, like what she was at the time for her sister, but for everyone. It makes you stop and think deeply about the wonder of the gift we call life. It's heart-wrenching, yes, but also incredibly inspirational and even humorous.

In this short clip from our hour-long interview, Andrea talks about how, as she wrote her story, she had to relive the pain of that experience all over again:

"To write this memoir the way I wanted to write it, I did have to relive it with the first draft. After I got past the first draft, it was much better. The first draft took me two years, and I had a therapist during that time specifically for this purpose. 

Every day I worked on the book it was painful, and I usually worked on it six days a week. It’s just like this wound that just starts to heal and you’re going to rip off the scab again. It was a very difficult time, it really was. And once I got the first draft done, I didn’t look at it for months, because I needed a breather from it. It was really really difficult. 

I work in my sister’s point of view. All of that writing, including going back and reading things that she had written in her journal—I didn’t read her journal until after she died—just that exercise in itself, spending a whole day reading her journal, was very emotional for me. She was a great writer."

✍Writing Tip of the Day: Show, Don't Tell

Andrea W. is the CEO and Co-founder of Cancer University, a for-profit, social-impact, health-tech startup. Her bestselling book "Better Off Bald: A Life in 147 Days" is a medical memoir about raising her younger sister Adrienne from the age of eight until she died from liver cancer at the age of 15. 

Andrea led a Writing Masterclass which I'll be sharing on Write With Impact Academy soon. In her class she shares several strategies she used to write her memoir. One of these is "Show, don't tell" -->

"I think it’s really important that you show and don’t tell. So, don’t tell me that you’re angry, show me what does anger look like. How does it feel? 

And that’s how you really hook people in, if they’re going through the experience with you.

Sometimes writers try too hard to tell readers what to feel, much like movies when they put too much music in and they’re telling us with the music exactly what to feel at exactly the right time. 

You have to trust your readers a bit more, and show them and trust them to infer whatever meaning that you’re trying to convey. And maybe they’ll get a different meaning out of it and that’s okay.

There’s a joke in my book that my sister made, and most people thought it was funny, a lot of people thought it was horrible. That’s okay.

I showed, and didn’t tell. With memoir, you have to be honest."

✍ Writing Tip of the Day: As You Go About Your Day, Think About What You're Going to Write About Next📝

In my recent interview with Pamela Wilson, Owner of Big Brand System and author of two bestselling books on content marketing and strategy, she shared a practical and easy-to-follow tip for writing--even while you're not writing:

"The most important thing that I did is what I did before I would sit down to write—besides drink a cup of coffee (you have to caffeinate)—I always had an idea for the piece of the book that I needed to write. 

I had these two blocks of time in my week when was going to be writing, but during the rest of the week when I wasn’t writing, when I was taking a walk, or washing dishes, or doing laundry, or cooking dinner, doing everyday tasks, I was thinking about the fact I needed to write a chapter about X, Y, or Z. And that primed my brain to be open to ideas or ways of thinking about it, or analogies I could use, or stories I could tell.

So, by the time I actually sat down to write I had some ideas. In some cases I would jot them down on a note on my phone. And then when I would sit down I would flesh out what I was already thinking. That was a huge help, just doing that pre-thinking before I sat down to write."

✍ Writing Tip of the Day: The 80-20 Rule of Writing 📝  

Pamela Wilson is the Owner of Big Brand System and bestselling author of two books on content marketing & strategy (links in the comments 👇)

She shared some practical advice for writing and publishing your first book on a recent Writing Masterclass for Write With Impact Academy. 

In this short clip she talks about the "80-20 rule of writing":

"I love it and you know this: The only way to get really good at writing is to write a lot. The beautiful thing about blogging and social media, when you write really rich content on social media, is by just doing it repetitively, the more you do it, the more comfortable you get with it. 

It’s like learning to speak a language.  You just keep speaking it until you feel fluent. That’s how writing has become for me. I’m a very confident writer now but I was not 10 years ago.

Beyond that I think the most important thing that you can do is just commit to writing. And sometimes it is easier to start on one of those platforms. 

It’s like a stream, where you write something and it moves down and it moves on, because it feels like a little bit less of a commitment.

But the other thing you can do is if you decide, for example, to start a blog, or you decide to do vlogging, and let’s say you’re posting a video every week, you can just make a commitment to once a week posting a piece of content. 

And just know that 80% of it will be kind of mediocre, and 20% will be amazing and make your name on the internet.

And that’s okay: the only way to get to that 20% that makes your name on the internet is to do the other 80% also, because it’s practice, your honing your voice, your honing your process, you’re getting better at the language that you’re learning to speak.

And that’s the purpose of it. So, all of those people you know who want to write, they just need to start. Jeff Goins says that, 'You’re a writer, start writing.' 

That’s how you become one, you just start doing it."

There’s a video clip on YouTube of Steve Jobs telling the story of when he was 12-years-old and he was looking for spare parts so he could build an electronic device known as a frequency counter. [VIDEO LINK IN THE COMMENTS]

He tells how he opened the Palo Alto phone book and located the number for Bill Hewlett, the founder of Hewlett-Packard, the company that made the parts he was seeking.

After introducing himself, Steve quickly got to the point: 

“I want to build a frequency counter, and I was wondering if you had any spare parts I could have...Bill not only gave me the parts I needed, he gave me a job that summer in Hewlett-Packard working on the assembly line putting nuts and bolts together on frequency counters. He got me a job in the place that built them. And I was in heaven.”

There have been many instances in my life where I’ve struggled to muster the courage to ask for something I wanted, fearing that my request would be refused, or that I would embarrass myself for even asking. Yet, in many of those instances, because I asked, the outcome turned out to be very positive.

There’s an art to asking for something you want, and at the right moment. Figuring out what someone needs and offering something of value to them can be an effective strategy for getting the “yes” that you’re looking for. 

Steve continues: “I’ve never found anyone who said ‘no’ or hung up the phone when I called,” says Steve. “I just asked. And when people ask me, I try to be responsive to pay that debt of gratitude back.”

✍ WRITING TIPS OF THE DAY: HOW TO WRITE A BUSINESS-SCHOOL APPLICATION ESSAY 💪🎓

27 years ago I wrote the application essay that helped me get accepted to Wharton's MBA program. I wrote about the "leadership lessons I learned from fishing."  Here are some tips that might help you if you're writing an essay soon:

💡 TIP 1: Write what you know 🧠
I struggled with some of the essays I wrote for other schools I applied to. But this one moved from my fingers to the keyboard a lot more effortlessly because I was able to draw from a deep well of memories that had been accumulating since I was a young boy.
 
💡 TIP 2: Write from the heart 💗
This is the flip-side of the point about writing what you know. It’s the creative, “right-brain” approach, compared to the coolly logical “left-brain” approach of drawing from the facts and figures stored in that vast database in your mind. 

I have a ton of fond memories from my days fishing as a kid with my dad and my brother. We enjoyed the beautiful ocean, lakes, and canals that I grew up surrounded by, and we connected deeply with nature through our fishing adventures. 

We also bonded as a family, and produced a lot of amazing dinner supplies as well, which my mom turned into culinary creations. I tried to capture some of these feelings in the essay I wrote for Wharton.

💡 TIP 3: Reveal something about yourself 🤦‍♂️
This can be tough, especially when trying to impress a group of tired admissions officers reading through thousands upon thousands of essays. 

You may not feel comfortable baring your soul, and that's okay. You don't need to over-share. But if you hope to have an impact on your reader that will last for more than a few fleeting moments, pry open the window and give them a peek into who you really are. 

💡 TIP 4: Tell a story 📃
Fiction writers seem to get all the glory for being able to craft stories that move the heart and the mind. But I believe there’s a lot that non-fiction writers can and should learn from fiction writers about creating memorable stories. 

As a writer of an application essay for business school, consider yourself a non-fiction storyteller writing the sort of stories that make those tired admissions officers sit up and say, “Hey, this one’s pretty good!”

Tell a story of a challenge you encountered, and describe how you overcame it—or maybe were overwhelmed by it. Maybe you failed at something, but then tell what you learned from that experience. Tell how you've grown from it and become the person that you are today.

💡 TIP 5: Edit obsessively 👌
I remember every time I thought my essay was done and ready to send in — it wasn’t. I sweated over my choice of words, syntax, grammar, spelling, and tone. I wrote and rewrote. Obsessively. 

My advice? Have at least one or two people — not your partner or mother — who can offer objective, hard-nosed feedback on your essay.

Normally I'm not a big fan of celebrating my own birthday, choosing to quickly and quietly move through the passage of each year without making a particular fuss.

Last November, on Thanksgiving Day, I underwent a 5-hour emergency operation that saved my life. 

In addition to gaining a new appreciation for my own life, I've also learned to appreciate even more deeply than ever before my mother. 

Looking at a photo of her holding me as a baby, I think about the sacrifices she made to raise me and my siblings, and to support my father through his busy career, his brief stint in local politics, and his weekend fishing trips. 

It certainly wasn't for lack of academic ability that she didn't pursue her own career. Growing up in a small steel town in Pittsburgh, my mother was a straight-A student who was accepted at Carnegie Tech University (renamed Carnegie-Mellon Univ.), which she attended for a brief time before dropping out to get married.

Too many people call a “productive” day one spent answering emails, hopping on calls, ticking boxes. That’s not productivity—it’s busyness. Efficiency isn't always efficient. 

True productivity is killing the project that never should’ve started, having the gritty chat that sharpens an idea, carving out thinking time, or bonding with a stakeholder who moves the needle. 

Productivity is often saying no, to ideas, to people, to misdirections, to distractions.

Most jobs are played on "defense"—people gathering evidence, dodging risks, avoiding decisions or even getting noticed.

Real productivity operates at three altitudes.

1️⃣ Effort – Hours logged, calls made, emails sent.

Easiest to track, easiest to fake.

2️⃣ Progress – Tasks done, outputs shipped, steps toward a goal.

What most think is sophisticated management, hence Elon’s note.

3️⃣ Impact – Did it matter? Did it change anything?

The only one worth a damn.

Impact isn’t about hours or checklists—it’s judgment, influence, playing offense. It’s quality of thought, decisions that stick, making a difference beyond your job title.

Build a pointless training course on time and under budget—productive? Sit on a team churning out something no one will buy—progress? Challenge a dumb KPI and shift a company’s focus to what counts—that’s impact.

Decided to do my first road trip in an EV, boy did I learn a lot.

Thoughts & serious recommendations ( based on Florida, non Tesla )
Clearly Europe /Tesla driving is wildly different.

Please note, it made me realize driving an EV far is entirely sensible, just nothing like as easy as it should be.

Key Takeaways & Recommendations

- Level 3 Chargers or Nothing
For daily use, home charging is amazing—like having a gas station at home.
But 85% of public chargers are below 50 kW, making them useless for road trips.
The U.S. has only 20,000 non-Tesla Level 3 chargers vs. 2 million gasoline pumps that are 10x faster.

- More Chargers in Fewer Locations
Less than 2 chargers per location is pointless.
At least 40% of chargers seem broken at any time, and 50% of “double chargers” are just two plugs on the same unit—only one car can charge.

Anxiety comes from uncertainty, so chargers should be in groups of 10+ per location.

- Stop “Topping Off”

The first 10 minutes of charging are MAGICAL—my Lucid gets 40 miles per minute at first.

But charging slows drastically as the battery fills. 10%-70% can take 25 mins, but 90%-100% can take an hour.

It’s absurd to see long lines while someone trickles in 2 miles per minute. Chargers should cut off at 80%. People are too ignorant to learn this.

- Better Locations 
Most chargers are where they’re easy to install, not where they’re needed.

EV owners need them in safe, well-lit locations near highways with something to do for 20-40 minutes.

Huge gas stations with 70+ pumps often have zero EV chargers—makes no sense.

- Massive Fragmentation

To do this trip, I needed 10 different apps, and even that wasn’t enough. There are 35+ charging networks.
You find random ones like 7 Eleven with the best and unused chargers because nobody knows ! 
Some apps aggregate data, but info is incomplete and unreliable.

- Real-Time Info Is Critical
You often can’t tell what’s ahead—broken chargers, long queues, chargers in employee-only lots, car parks closed at 6 PM, etc.

- Everything Is Too Complicated
Imagine if every gas pump required an app.
Imagine if 50% of pumps stopped halfway through, and pricing was per kWh, per minute, and had extra fees for entering the station.
That’s the EV charging experience today—a bizarre mess from lack of care and thought.

Fixing This: A Simple Blueprint

- More DC chargers, grouped in big locations (10+ per site).
- Stop charging past 80%.
- Allow credit card payments, no more apps.
- Fine companies for broken chargers.
- National chains should own this (Love’s, Racetrak, Walmart?).
- One world-class app to show all chargers in real time—spend $10M on this, not $7.5B on 7 chargers ( digital infrastructure is often more vital than physical, it's resourceful allocation) 

- Clear queuing systems so people know where to line up ( painted lines and signs and only one access point please ) 

I still love my non-Tesla EV and will buy another, but charging infrastructure needs urgent fixes

Is It just more data, or something else?
I used to think self-driving cars would never work.

How could a car, at 60mph, tell the difference between a rock and an empty crisp packet? 
How could it sense, from body language alone, that a child was about to run after a ball? 
How could it detect improbable things from context the way humans do ( very easily and without thinking about it)?

Well, I was wrong.

It turns out that with enough sensors, enough scenarios, and enough data, machines can essentially feel like people. 
Body language, intent, uncertainty—these aren’t magic. They’re just more data points.

And that’s the real question with AI: 
Which problems are solved by more data and which ones need something different?

Can AI be creative if we just feed it more examples?
Can AI design buildings that work, or only copy what exists?
Can AI create new scientific understanding, or just optimize old knowledge?

Can AI tell if a joke is funny? Predict if a tweet will go viral? Know if a song will be loved?

Is it thinking, or just mimicking thought?

AI is getting better, but how much better? When do we need something else.

You can ask AI to design a building, but it doesn't know what a building is, it doesn't know what a kitchen is,  it doesn't know what sunlight is, it doesn't know how people live, it doesn't know about problems with overheating, it doesn't know what a view is, what beauty is, but what if it never needed to? 
What if enough pictures of good, buildable, livable, code passing, zone pleasing homes are fed into it, that it can still work?

Or will we always need something that understands, and thats a different thing.

Where is it actually useful, or valuable, these things are not the same.

How do we deploy it, and what does that mean for creativity, business, and the future?

More data solves more things. But does it solve everything? And does that matter? 

Some takeouts:

1) Challenge the "More Data = Smarter AI" Assumption
Not every problem is solved by throwing more data at it. 

2) Test AI on what It ynderstands, not just what It predicts
AI can optimize ads, detect fraud, and predict behavior but can it explain why?  Push for AI systems that don’t just give results but provide deeper reasoning.

3) Focus on Deployment, not just Development
AI’s success isn’t about being impressive in a demo. The real challenge is applying it meaningfully in business, design, and society. Where will it actually create value?

4) Stay skeptical—But open-minded
AI’s future isn’t preordained. Some problems will be solved with scale, others need entirely new approaches. The key is knowing which is which.

One of the most common criticisms of generative AI isn’t particularly true: the idea that it can’t be creative.

Creativity is strange and poorly defined. 

We explain it with words like ‘imagination’ or ‘original ideas,’ and think of it like Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart’s definition of pornography: “I’ll know it when I see it.”

We’re quick to assume machines and data can’t be creative because they can’t dream or imagine or be original. 

But the sad reality is that most humans aren’t as creative as we think, nor original.

Ask pretty much ANY seven-year-old on the planet to draw a house, and you’re unlikely to see a curvaceous cocoon-like home, Fallingwater, or Villa Savoye. 

You’ll almost certainly get a rectangle, a garden path, a chimney, four windows, and (oddly) a happy couple.

Over time, our creativity gets beaten out of us.
- To be creative is to be vulnerable-it means standing out.
- To be creative is to be exhausted-it means constantly challenging assumptions.

Creativity is less a mind state and more a process. 
It’s the combination of new ideas, unlikely connections, unexpected contexts, and approaching familiar things in unfamiliar ways.


To some extent, generative AI can do this because of its sheer processing power.

When engineers wanted a better 3D antenna design, AI produced something so convoluted, complex, messy—and perfect—that no human would have suggested it. 

The optimal chassis for a Formula One car, blending strength and weight, doesn’t look like something designed in Excel; it looks like it came from another universe. 

Architecture generated by genAI could resemble beehive cones or seashells because AI doesn’t assume that anyone who has a sofa thats not flat against a back wall, will go a bit nuts. 


In many ways generative AI can be creative, if we tell it to.

We can dial up the temperature in generative AI, making outputs more random and diverse, akin to ‘more creative.’ 

We can adjust the top-p (nucleus sampling) setting to a higher value, allowing AI to choose from a wider range of possible outputs, encouraging unexpected combinations that resemble ‘imagination.’

That’s what’s fascinating about AI discussions. 
The more we describe its workings in human terms—imagination, memory, thinking, understanding, creativity—the more we misunderstand it.

Yes, like humans, it matches patterns, uses past experience, makes predictions, and guesses what people mean in specific contexts.

But no, it’s not thinking, understanding, or imagining. It’s not embarrassed to be wrong or trying to please anyone.

While AI can mimic aspects of human thinking, it’s fundamentally different—more like a mirror reflecting back what it’s seen, rather than a mind experiencing the world.

But if the outputs are the same, better, or interestingly different… does it matter?

There is a lot more money to be made proving that something that doesn’t work, works. 
........Than making something that absolutely works, is known to work, but in ways we can’t track. 

Theres a lot more money in making something complex and scary, than showing how something is simple and advantageous. 

There’s far greater demand for immediate impact that’s not significant or sustainable, than long term impact that can transform a companies future.

What rules will AI change?
It’s one of the best questions out there.

Some context -
The first big wave of change in our lives was the era of Computing & Connectivity.

Desktops, Mobile phones, 3G, Wifi, Cloud computing,Big Data and more, all combined to form a new platform for business.

Creating shifts in the “rules of business”, some examples ( there are way more that I cover in my books) 
-----
1) Blurred lines.

We knew what a Bank was in 1990, but by 2010 Banks, Neobanks, digital wallets, payment layers had blurred the picture. Payment apps in China had greater cash deposits than most banks in the world. 

This made many companies become horizontal, Google, Amazon, WeChat could be ANYTHING, by sitting on top and owning the customer interface.

2) Geography vanished. 

The BBC spent over 100 years to not enter the USA, or any other country.
Netflix flicked a switch in jan 2016 to enter 130 new countries.
They didn't need an office, they didn't need lawyers, they needed to change a setting on servers and new payment pages.
From Upwork to YouTube to Temu to Only Fans, boundaries have never been less relevant.

3) Easier to build than change.

Ever noticed how Chase UK has a better banking app than Chase in the USA? It’s because one is a giant mess of old code, technical debt, old reporting and layers hastily added on to glue it together, but the new banking app started from scratch.

4) Direct to Consumer 

Retailers and Wholesalers in many industries could be cut out, especially with digital services.
Why do Car companies need showrooms, when the internet is it, why put products on shelves if Instagram is the shelf now. 

5) Brands became more important

The Internet made the entire world the store.
We have more products and more brands than ever
At the same time we knew less about them. We had less trust. We couldn't touch things before we bought them.

So the interesting questions:

If AI/Gen AI is a new era of change, what old rules does it smash, what new rules does it create?

How does it change the rules of business?
How does it alter Consumer behaviors?
How does it change Consumer expectations?

We can now move from a Whopper to a Big Mac by moving our finger one inch to a different app, we can now change payment cards with a few clicks, we are now used to seeing services in real time, what you behaviors and expectations emerge?

Be great to get your thoughts?

I'm yet to be convinced that brands will be less important.
I'm yet to believe the shopping will be done for us by bots.

But there will be MANY changes, and things that are very hard to imagine right now.
But in hindsight will seem inevitable.

Almost everything people wrote about Disruption was wrong, yes, including the late Clayton Christensen.

Uber didn't disrupt Taxis by being cheaper, or having a lower cost base, it was a better user experience.

Airbnb didn't disrupt Hotels by being cheaper, it opened an adjacent market.

The iPhone wasn't a cheaper Laptop or Phone, it was a radically different thing.

Disruption was asking "What if the rules were different?"

Disruption is merely challenging assumptions that hold us back.

Disruption isn't about technology at all. Disruption is about imagination, courage, audacity, empathy.

Now, quite often Disruption IS about technology.

Netflix thrived because streaming meant media could be on demand, it meant 160 countries could come on tap, with no new offices or staff

Shein thrives because rather than sending 40,000 SKUs a week to stores, it can take pictures of 40,000 and only make in volume what people like. 

Often it's nothing to do with tech, it's thinking.
 
Nespresso was an amazing disruption because it challenged the notion people would spend $50 a month on coffee at home.

Dyson challenged the idea people cared enough to spend $500 on a vacuum. 

Nest challenged the idea that Thermostats could ever be bought by end users.

But often it's more complex.

Tesla can thrive because when you change how cars are made, you can change how they are designed, you can change how they are bought and distributed  you can change how they are serviced, you can change how they are financed, and marketed.

It turns out progress is about the parameters of possibility, about regulation, consumer behavior, business models, but most of all about the assumptions that hold you back.

Disruption isn't doing everything differently. 

It's the confidence to ensure your progress is shaped by the parameters that others back and constrains drive you forward to a better place.

And technology is interesting, because it allows old rules to be broken.

It can reconcile long assumed trade offs.
It makes building something new, easier than changing something old.
It makes imagination the limit more than engineering.
It makes agility sometimes  more important than experience.
It makes ambition more important than assets.

It's not about the channel, it's not about the KPI, it's not about the response mechanism, it's what period it's designed to make a difference.

LONG
We'd have activity ( not just ads) designed to impact business over periods of 2+ years, we'd call this "long" term marketing

SHORT 
We'd have activity designed to impact business over periods of < 1 month -  "short" term marketing

CAMPAIGN
We'd have activity designed to impact business over periods of 1 month - 2 years.  "Medium" term marketing

We wouldn't go around with nonsense terms like performance marketing, which suggests "brand" ads don't perform.

We'd not stupidly think "digital" can only be used for immediate impact, just because we CAN use it this way.

Tom Goodwin's post 2mo ago:
Remember when voice search was supposed to be 50% of all searches by 2020?  One of the dumbest ever predictions. 

Or how Alexa was going to revolutionize shopping? 

Or chatbots were going to take over customer service?

These ideas flopped because they made people work too hard. 

Conversational interfaces have always struggled because, who has the patience? Typing is faster. Scrolling is easier. Swiping takes zero effort. And learning new ways to do things is slow.

But then Generative AI came along and started reshaping things, creating new plasticity in habits.

- Why read a 300-page business book when you could save 8 hours by asking AI three laser-focused questions?

- Why skim a newspaper cover to cover when you could say, “Tell me five things that matter today,” and go deeper on the ones that intrigue you? "is Trump really going to to be able to change Birthright law" can save you 10 hours of outrage driven reading.

- Why send clients a static deck when your company’s creds could be an interactive chat, where they ask exactly what they want to know?

- What if training courses weren’t 20 hours of linear videos, but 5-minute interactive sessions whenever someone had a question? 

- What if instruction manuals or contracts became conversations?

The truth about new tech is that it’s not just about the tech—it’s about building the muscles and habits to use it.

- Watching my first boss double-click a mouse was excruciating—it didn’t come naturally.
- Seeing people send Outlook invites in 2002 felt clunky—it wasn’t “what we did.”
- Even using voice-to-text today is awkward because our brains don’t naturally think how we write.

But here’s the thing:

1) Younger generations are growing up native to these tools.
2) Older generations are adapting (slowly, but surely).

In a year, so much of what we do could be conversational—but only in the right places. Knowing what will work and what won’t is key.

I don’t think we’ll shop through conversations—trust and visual options are still too important.

I don’t think entertainment will come this way—TikTok proves we want zero effort there.

But news? Research? Sales? Contracts? Insurance? Absolutely ripe for conversational reinvention.

Imagine buying travel insurance or getting personalized advice on car loans, or finally understanding what’s buried in a 20-page warranty.

Combine it with agents / swarms etc and it can go even further, here are 4 things in need with Auto insurance, get me the best deal,  for example.

Generative AI won’t change everything, but it’s going to re-engineer huge chunks of customer journeys—and spotting those opportunities is where the magic lies.

The process of considering what it won't change is even more important, I'll still be in TJMaxx obsessing over finding once again a copper saucepan with a mislabeled price.

AI for me always stands for the "Average of the Internet"

Thanks to AI, we are getting closer to a better definition of what an insight is.

It's a useful finding that could NEVER come from AI

For far too long we've let people talk about "Data Driven Insights", a statement that's much loved because of poetic alliteration and our love of the idea that Data has the answer and that rational thinking is always the way.

I'd be very happy to respect and value DDI , if anyone had ever given me some examples. People buy more iceberg lettuce when it's rainy, isn't one.

For me an insight is the opposite to the process of Generative AI

If Gen AI is process based on logical averaging of common previously expressed ideas and wisdom, and mapping how things relate each other, then an insight is the opposite.

It's something novel, unlikely, observed more than recorded, it's something beyond mere data.

So next time you're sold on AI derived Insights, remember that if you're thinking the same way, using the same tools and the same data, as anyone else on the planet, you're destined to be at best, as good as everyone else.

This isn't to say that data that isn't an insight is useless

And it's not to say that insights are necessary much of the time, we never need them in ads for example.

But let's be clear on what AI is and isn't good for
And let's be clear on what words actually mean.

This means modular or prefab construction is unscalable, it means every home is custom, made on site, and the time and complexity and risk of building is massive.

4) At the same time most houses need mortgages, and to get a mortgage you need to show market value. Market value comes from Comps and comps largely ignore quality of construction, pleasantness of views, the wonderful walnut floorboards or the magical landscaping. Market value comes from spreadsheets where homes are turned into cost per square sq ft. Which largely comes from the zipcode.

5) So if you're spending $600k on land, $150k on fees, spend 1 year getting permits, a year building, and construction costs $350 per sq ft,  and you home may sell for $800 per sq ft, you can either

- Build a boring 5,000 sq ft home for $2.5m worth $4m
- Build a wonderful  2,500 sq ft home for $1.625m worth $2m
- Build an affordable cosy, homely starter 1,200 sq ft home for $1.170m worth $960k

So the whole market for small, cheap, accessible, homely homes makes no sense.

People in large homes who don't need them, can't find smaller places to move into.
People looking for starter home can't find them,
People who want quality construction, architectural merit, or smaller luxury homes on larger lots, can't get mortgages to buy them.

The whole system needs to change 
1) Zoning that allows for smaller houses
2) Far more standardized planning regulations
3) Far more use of prefab, kit and modular homes.
4) Far faster permitting process
5) More imaginative valuations of homes based on desirability not cost per area.
6) A culture where people buy homes to relish living in, not as the safest, most fungible asset class.

There are two great things about Linkedin and two terrible things.

A) The Great:

1) Conversational threading.
When I post on Substack thousands of people read it and 2-3 people comment.

It's absolutely brilliant as a writer to be able to listen to people, to prompt conversation, to learn from others, and I appreciate that this is one place where lots of people join in and debate and the quality of people you can access is unparalleled. 

2) Profiles are named.
Conversations on here are largely civil, mostly constructive and quite often expert and thought through.

I think this is because this site started as a professional network, and people's reputation is attached to their real identity and their contributions on here.   Again, this is quite unique and explains my point 1 , above.

B) The Bad.

1) Suppressed content. 
I now get about five messages a week from people who wonder what happened to me. They say I've vanished. 

They say they've always actively engaged in my stuff, but haven't seen it for weeks/months. They've chosen to follow me, but don't see me. They thought I'd had an accident or got writers block, or worse still , a job.

I've not been shadow banned, it's not a conspiracy, but clearly some algorithm God just doesn't think my stuff is worth seeing.

I find it really odd that people have taken then steps to tell a site "I want to see their stuff" , have their wishes overwritten by an algo.

We also see that any links off site quickly die. Perish the thought a meaty white paper, a substantial presentation, an gem of an article, would provide value and dare be hosted anywhere else.

I wish Linkedin would take your wishes above theirs.

2) Suggested content.

The reason algos suggest content is because if we merely saw people who we'd followed, but saw everything they ever wrote, we'd be inundated. 

So as part of deciding not to show you stuff, they show you things that seem to loved by other people a bit like you.

The issue is that the vast majority of people like crap.
They like simplistic
They engage in empty positivity.
They type "Gold" to get the "10 tips for Gold"
They comment on stuff that makes them angry.
They fall for the Clickbait.

So over time, people learn to write in such a way as to remove complexity, add a selfie, offer banal platitudes, and get people angry.

It would be nice if algorithmic feeds could take a background role, show us what we've asked for, and let people be the mechanism by which new content, new people and new ideas are discovered.

I'd share so much more stuff if I thought it would actually be viewed and help. I'd suggest so many people to follow, if Linkedin didn't already.

Of the top 20 movies at the box office last year, 18 were sequels.

2000: 18 original, 2 sequels.
2010: 9 original, 11 sequels.
2024: 2 original, 18 sequels.

I take two things away from this,
1) Brands are more important than ever.

We've got too much choice and too little energy to think, so brands proliferate in every direction. 

One of the big trends that nobody talks about is the brands are entering ever more areas of our life, prescription medication, condo buildings, dental care, hair salons, franchises and brands will take over every industry.

2) A culture of data always reinforces the past.

The business of movie making, is really the business of risk.

Over the years, it's become less of an artistic expression and more of a return on investment industry.

Sequels rarely perform spectacularly. Sequels often perform in mediocre ways. 

If you wanted to maximize potential ROI, you would take a VC like approach, you'd make a lot of bets and take risks.  You'd make Paranormal Activity, Mad Max, Napoleon Dynamite, Pulp Fiction.

But in a culture of data, it's more important to be predictable than remarkable.

Or in the words of Ed Catmull...... "With certain ideas, you can predict commercial success. So with a 'Toy Story 3' or a 'Cars 2,' you know the idea is more likely to have financial success" 

I think that's where we are these days.

It's far better for many people in their career to perform worse, but more predictively, more safely, more conventionally. Than it is for them to be remarkable, be proud of what they can make happen, and to be excited about the change they bring to the world.

And a culture of data ensures that this is the only way to be.

Why is Digital Transformation So Slow?

It’s a question I can’t stop thinking about.

Why do so many companies still use bad software? Why aren’t airlines competing with world-class apps? Why don’t banks dominate the digital landscape and showcase their brilliance?

For years, I chalked it up to resistance to change, apathy, and a lack of ambition. Three big culprits seemed obvious:

1️⃣ The End-User Problem: CEOs often don’t see how clunky tools hurt employees.

2️⃣ The Business Case for Change: Overhauls are costly, and better apps don’t always feel “core” to the business.

3️⃣ Lack of Talent: Many organizations simply don’t have access to the expertise needed.

But recently, I’ve uncovered a deeper, less-discussed factor: the fear of software license audits.

Here’s how it plays out: As companies grow, their software spreads across departments, offices, and acquisitions—sometimes in ways that unintentionally skirt evolving license terms. 

Marketing adopts what was once just for Sales. 
Newly opened offices embrace the same software. 
Acquired companies are asked to use it too.

Meanwhile, license terms quietly evolve, adding sneaky clauses that can turn everyday usage into potential infractions. It all seems fine—until the software vendor initiates a license audit.

These audits are the ultimate power move. Vendors know exactly how their software is used and where companies may inadvertently breach license conditions. They leverage this knowledge to threaten fines, cause disruption, and maintain control.

This creates a chilling effect:
-They don’t argue about price hikes.
 -They don’t push for better support.
 -They don’t modernize.

The fear of audits locks companies into outdated systems, stalls transformation, and reinforces a power dynamic where vendors prioritize control over innovation.

Interestingly, many enterprise companies are looking to third-party support to free up budget for digital transformation—but fear comes into play here too. 

Companies worry that switching to third-party support will automatically trigger audits.

Here’s the truth: Audits are rarely triggered solely by moving to third-party support and importantly, companies are fully within their rights to switch their maintenance contracts.

Third-party support providers, like Spinnaker Support, specialize in helping companies manage critical systems—whether it’s Oracle, SAP, or VMware—while delivering benefits like enhanced security, better quality support, and significant cost savings. 
While third-party support can’t eliminate the possibility of audits, it gives companies the freedom to prioritize their business goals without fear.

In short, don’t let the fear of audits stall your progress. Digital transformation is possible, but it starts by questioning what’s holding you back and finding partners who align with your goals.

#WomensHistoryMonth

She’s widely recognized, often stopped in airports by people touched by her work. And after our screening, she stayed to take photos and chat with hundreds of attendees.

I think, like me, they admire what she stands for: that there is beauty and value in our differences, that diverse ways of thinking drive innovation, and that neurodiversity is vital to society.

As she says: “The world needs all kinds of minds.”

I was honored to represent the National Women's Hall of Fame, which exists to share the stories of extraordinary women like Dr. Grandin.

Right now, as your marketing teams read this, they're hoping you'll see it - or that someone will be brave enough to share it with you.

The solution starts with you. What are you going to incentivize?

First, let’s explain what’s actually going on. This is all based on a report from The Information, whose sources at OpenAI said that the company has found the performance improvements of their latest model Orion to be not as significant as previous jumps in the state of the art. There’s some reporting that Google’s dealing with the same thing with the latest version of Gemini.

The nuance is that the challenge seems to be about the limitations of the previous method for scaling LLMs, which was throwing more data and compute at them during the pre-training process.

Turns out, that’s not the only way to increase capabilities.

We’ve already gotten a preview of this with OpenAI’s o1 “reasoning” model. That model uses a strategy called “test-time compute” which is a different approach during the inference phase, which happens after the model has been prompted.

The point is: just because one approach to scaling is showing limitations doesn’t mean that model advances are going to stop.

What’s more, when it comes to the question of enterprise AI transformation, it’s not really about the state of the art.

Instead, AI transformation is about analyzing existing workflows and processes and asking whether there is an AI powered alternative - be it an AI-assisted human process or an Agent automated process, that would be more effective - in a never-ending loop.

GenAI transformation is the defining challenge and opportunity for enterprises right now. Here are 5 big blockers to enterprise AI adoption.

1. Unclear mandates
AI transformation has to start from the top. Not only do executives need to be talking about GenAI, they need to be using GenAI, and they need to be painting a vision for the company’s future empowered by GenAI. Employees need to know that 1) GenAI adoption is a priority; and that 2) it’s a priority not because leadership wants to fire half the company and do the same with less, but because they want to realize the AI opportunity to do more and better things than we’re ever possible before.

2. Invisible Usage
One of the reasons that clear mandates from the top are so important is that right now much of AI usage in the enterprise is invisible - either because there aren’t systems for sharing (see below) or because employees are purposefully keeping their AI use secret. Many employees using AI are worried they’re breaking rules, worried their work will not be treated as legitimate, or worried that using AI will make them seem replaceable. Microsoft/LinkedIn found that of the 75% of knowledge workers using AI, 78% weren’t telling anyone about it.

3. Use Case Confusion
GenAI is self evidently powerful. Exactly what to use GenAI for to get value, however, is less clear. Most companies are still at the stage where every employee has to act like a use case explorer, tinkering, experimenting, and hopefully finding something that works. This is radically inefficient, and leads to anemic adoption and lots of repeated mistakes. By the way, invisible usage exacerbates this problem. Invisible usage means that people don’t get to learn from each other’s experience.

4. No Systems for Sharing Best Practices
Sometimes usage is invisible because employees are worried about the reaction to them using AI. But a lot of times it’s invisible because there simply aren’t currently structures and systems for them to share what they’re learning. Companies need robust, ideally software driven systems for capturing information about AI usage and distributing best practices across the organization. ahem superintelligent ahem

5. Inertia and a Need for Evangelism
The constraining factor on AI won’t be technological, it will be based on human and organizational inertia. Increasingly, we’re seeing enterprises recognize that even as they create mandates, and work to build systems for sharing, they need to be loud about that work. We’re even seeing (and helping!) some companies start entire internal facing marketing campaigns evangelizing AI use.

This is the most important AI term you’re going to start seeing everywhere:

Service-as-a-Software.

So, what does it mean?

Up to now, SaaS has referred to “Software-as-a-Service.” It referred to a new way of provisioning software in the cloud. Over the last decade and a half, SaaS companies became integrated with just about every business workflow that exists. Enterprises could simply subscribe to the software, turning it off and on and expanding and contracting the size of their engagement at will. In general, SaaS worked on a cost-per-seat business model.

Moving forward, generative AI will remake pretty much every business workflow once again. Broadly speaking; remaking will take two forms:
1. Improved workflows undertaken AI-assisted humans
2. Improved workflows undertaken by AI agents, managed by humans and/or other AI’s

Service-as-a-Software is the natural result of AI agent implemented workflows. In this model, the companies provisioning agents aren’t selling software that improve’s human work, but actually selling a version of the labor itself.

One of the most consequential changes emerging is around business model. When you’re selling the work itself, rather than an assistant to work, the per-seat model ceases to make sense. The new exploration is in pricing the actual outcomes and output.

We’re at the very early innings of this transition. How agents get integrated into existing processes is still a wide-open question. It’s also still too early to know how the business model norms will resolve.

Still, it’s a big, consequential change, and one that you’re going to hear a lot more about in the months to come.

Here's something most companies will get wrong about AI at first:

AI is a "more with the same" tech, not a "the same with less" tech. 

Aaron Levie framed this on X this morning [see attached image] around Jevon's Paradox -- that increasing the efficiency of a resource actually tends to increase demand for the resource. 

An unacknowledged assumption in a lot of the fears around AI is that the current demand we have for [everything] is the natural or max demand society has for that thing. So if that thing can be provisioned with far fewer resources, that means less work for the people doing the provisioning. 

For example: if code is 1/10th as hard to create, then we'll only need 1/10th the coders. 

The history of human experience shows us, however, that our ability to expand demand and consume more is pretty much endless. If code is 1/10th as hard to create, we wont have 1/10th the coders; we'll just produce 10x as much code. 

In fact, even that is probably wrong. If code becomes 1/10th as hard to create, not only will today's coders produce 10x, but a whole new wave of people who wouldn't have been creating code before will get involved, so the net impact will be even more than 10x the code. 

Bringing this back to companies, MANY are going to fall into the trap of thinking that AI is a "doing the same with less" technology, where they can get the same output with lower input costs. Initially, these companies may even be rewarded by markets focused entirely on the short-term who love cost cutting. 

It won't take long, however, before they start to be wildly outcompeted by companies who realize that the real opportunity isn't "the same with less," but "more with the same," (and eventually even "much, much, much more output with just a little more input"). 

The faster we can get bigco's thinking in "more with the same" terms, rather than "the same with less" terms, the better for everyone.

5 Reasons Workers Are Keeping AI Use Secret

What’s true: workers are using AI. A Microsoft/LinkedIn study from earlier this year found 75% of knowledge workers using AI. A McKinsey survey from August put it at 91%.

What’s also true: they’re keeping their usage quiet, if not outright secret. That first survey also found that, of those using AI, 78% weren’t telling any one.

Ethan Mollick called these users “Secret Cyborgs” and discussed why they’re keeping their AI use secret in a recent essay [linked in comments]. Riffing off that and adding my own experience, here are 5 reasons workers are keeping their AI use secret:

1. They’re not sure what their company thinks about AI use. Most companies haven’t done a great job yet being clear about what is and isn’t okay. In many cases, that’s because they haven’t decided what is and isn’t okay. But given that workers are trying to do work better, not break rules, until there is more clarity, they’re keeping quiet.

2. They don’t want their work to be seen as illegitimate. Work culture often focuses on measures of inputs like how long someone worked on something as a proxy for quality. This can easily lead to a fear of AI-enabled work being perceived as somehow “cheating.”

3. They don’t want more work. Who owns the productivity gain of AI usage? Is it the employee who does things 25% faster and now has more time for other things, or is it the company who can now assign 25% more work. Some AI smuggling behavior is a byproduct of a fear that employers will just fill in newly available time with more tasks.

4. There’s no good way to share what they’re doing. Even if a person wanted to tell all of their colleagues about the valuable use cases and new AI workflows they’ve uncovered, what’s the mechanism to do so? Enterprises new scalable systems to make AI usage visible. This is the central problem Superintelligent is solving.

5. Simply put: they’re terrified someone is going to tell them they’re not allowed to use AI anymore. Once you go from a non-AI workflow to an AI-enabled workflow, most people truly can’t imagine going backwards. If there is ANY chance that revealing AI usage could lead to being told you’re not allowed to do that thing which makes your worklife so much better, people are going to stay silent.

Still, the sheer quantity of announcements meant that most people weren't comparing whose AI assistant was the most state of the art. Even more than that, it's clear from I/O that Google isn't going after the AI Twitter community — they're going after the mass market of future potential AI users.

This is the most divisive OpenAI announcement event we've ever seen.

Some feel like they've glimpsed the future; Samantha from Her or Jarvis from Iron Man brought to life. Others are left saying "that's it?"

Part of this is about what this wasn't: it wasn't an announcement about GPT4.5 or GPT-5. There is so much attention on the state of the art horserace that for some, anything less than that was going to be a disappointment no matter what.

What this was, ultimately, was a product announcement. OpenAI is betting on a totally new mode of interacting with AI. The breakout experience was the chatbot of ChatGPT, but this announcement shows that their bet on the future of human-AI interactions is actually chatting with voice and vision.

Product announcements are going to inherently be more divisive than technology announcements because it's harder to tell if a product is going to be truly different until you actually interact with it. And especially when it comes to a different mode of human-computer interaction, there is even more room for diverse beliefs about how useful it's going to be.

That said, the fact that there wasn't a GPT4.5 or GPT5 announced is also distracting people from the technological advancement that this is a natively multimodal model. It's not a text model with a voice or image addition; it is multimodal token in, multimodal token out. This opens up a huge array of use cases that are going to take some time to filter into the consciousness.

Lastly, and most practically, it's hugely significant that they've made this model available for free to everyone, as well as making the API 50% cheaper. That is a MASSIVE increase in accessibility.

Top 3 things from the announcement:

3 - Truly natively multimodal model - this will likely transform use cases for ChatGPT as much or more as increasing the intelligence of the underlying model

2 - Free access to their most advance model - huge transformation in accessibility

1 - OpenAI's big bet on a new mode of interaction - OpenAI's like they're making a huge bet that Her-style interactions will replace typing to chatbots as the way we interact with AI

Why a Turing Award Winner Quit Google to Warn About AI

The AI safety question isn’t new. What’s new is:

•GPT-4 (and other recent AI advances) having capabilities that many thought were years away
•An all-consuming AI arms race in big tech
•Hundreds of millions of new AI users grappling with AI safety questions for the first time

On that last point, my sense is that a lot of people just don’t know what to think. On the one hand, the arguments of the safety folks - coming through Bankless interviews or whatever transmission channel they come through - are compelling, and scary. On the other, things really can’t be that bad, right?

Geoffrey Hinton seems to think they might be. Dr. Hinton is a pioneer of neural networks, something he started working on in 1972. In 2012, he built a neural network that could identify objects in photos with two students - one who would go on to be chief scientist at OpenAI. A company around it was soon acquired by Google. In 2018, Hinton’s work on neural networks won the Turing Award which is seen as akin to the Nobel Prize in computing.

Over the last year, Hinton has gotten increasingly uncomfortable with the industry he helped found. There are a few reasons why. For one, the rate of change is faster than anyone expected. “Look at how it was five years ago and how it is now. Take the difference and propagate it forward. That’s scary.”

On top of that, he sees an arms race that will be nigh impossible to slow down. Microsoft jumping out ahead of Google on AI triggered a response from Google that, in Hinton’s estimation, undermined their previous stance of being careful not to release something that might cause harm.

So what is Hinton worried about? Kinda all of it. Fake information flooding the internet. A massive upheaval in the jobs market. Nefarious actors purposefully using it to do bad things. And well, even worse.

“The idea that this stuff could actually get smarter than people — a few people believed that. But most people thought it was way off. And I thought it was way off. I thought it was 30 to 50 years or even longer away. Obviously, I no longer think that.”

Medium Capitalism

OpenAI and their best-known creation ChatGPT have become so ubiquitous, so at the core of this new digital and economic paradigm, that it can be jarring to remember that they aren't just some public good like an internet protocol but are, in fact, a company.

That means shareholders. That means economic incentives. That means business decisions, not just tech decisions. OpenAI made a bunch of business decisions for ChatGPT this week.

The first is a privacy-focused update. ChatGPT users can now turn off chat history. Think incognito browsing for a comparison. When chat history is turned off, OpenAI won't use those chats to train their models, and all chats are permanently deleted after 30 days.

The second business decision is, well, ChatGPT business. It's a forthcoming subscription services "for professionals who need more control over their data as well as enterprises seeking to manage their end users." By default these customers' data won't be used to train their models.

Yesterday they also released brand guidelines which are meant to crack down on how many projects slap "GPT" on the back of a word and call it a day.

Now, going back to this idea of economic incentives, OpenAI's are designed at least to be a little different than others. The company started in 2015 as a nonprofit, but in 2019 created a for-profit vehicle as well. In a recent interview with Lex Fridman, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said:

"We had tried and failed enough to raise the money as a nonprofit. We didn’t see a path forward there. So we needed some of the benefits of capitalism, but not too much. I remember at the time, someone said, you know, as a nonprofit, not enough will happen. As a for profit, too much will happen. So we need this sort of strange intermediate."

Part of that "strange intermediate" was capping returns at 100x for early investors (the cap has gotten lower for later investors). On the one hand, 100x doesn't seem like too bad a return. On the other hand, AGI (assuming, you know, we live) probably returns a hell of a lot more than 100x.

Which is why so many other companies are racing at it with far less caution and consideration (and frankly, far more money). In that environment, even with the lead OpenAI has, can this vision of Medium Capitalism win?

Someone recently shared with me that they used to see feedback as an attack. I can see that. Defensiveness is a natural response. But they learned something critical: Feedback — even hard feedback — improves outcomes. I have come to seek it out from trusted colleagues and customers, especially when making difficult decisions.

Here is how I approach feedback now:
1. Listen without reacting. Imagine you are floating above the scene. Focus on understanding the sharer's perspective rather than preparing your defense.
2. Ask clarifying questions. What am I missing? How could I make this approach better?
3. Take time to reflect. Feedback often reveals gaps or opportunities you might not have seen.
4. Apply what resonates. Not all feedback will be actionable, but the best often challenges you to think differently.

Feedback is not about personal judgment — it is about improving outcomes for everyone involved. When you see it this way, you start to actively seek it rather than avoid it.

If you are a leader in title or action, now is the time to create space for what truly matters: what is top priority based on the intersection of your skills, the team's needs, and where your influence will be most felt.

Connection is easy to talk about, hard to cultivate. This is even more true for 100% remote teams.

- Set our upcoming annual plan in December
- Ensure that we have a core set of themes
- Avoid a lot of conference room meetings
- Assign a book that the entire company reads and discusses 
- Do cross-team fun activities

#Strategy #Startups

How do you realize tangible product value with as little effort (and friction) as possible?

Our team at Aha! has started calling this just-enough view of product development the “Minimum Tolerable Process” (MTP).

Note that we chose to call it “tolerable,” not “lovable.” 

Few people aside from consultants and theorists love (and get paid for) process. So the focus here is pursuing the minimum overhead needed to effectively deliver what customers will love — and for the team to be happy doing that work. 

You start by removing the friction that typically occurs when there is tension and conflict around objectives and accountability. And you continue by removing every meeting that is not absolutely required. 

To succeed, you need real insights and a true north. And you have to establish some defined ways of working. (Otherwise, you are relying on luck and are sure to experience chaos.) 

So how do you know if you are very far from or very near to your own MTP?

When I inevitably asked if the prospect had committed to buying the product if we built this random feature, my question was viewed with disdain. 

After a few back-and-forths, I quickly learned that this person would always go to the CEO after to see if they could get the answer they wanted.

I could have stopped there and pushed the blame onto the VP — but that would have done us both a disservice. Instead, I took the time to reflect on why this person felt the need to escalate. 

I realized that I had not given the VP full context behind why we were prioritizing certain features ahead of others. I made sure to set up a recurring 1:1 roadmap review so we could identify where priorities diverged and better understand each other.

Brian de Haaff's post 8mo ago:
You can make plenty of arguments for why remote is better or worse than working in person. 

But blaming remote work for a company’s productivity is obfuscation. That level of dysfunction is bigger than an office building. 

Mismanagement, unclear goals, no transparency into work, lack of urgency: These are the real culprits.

In my experience, remote work gives you the opportunity to be your best from anywhere. 

And after more than a decade of leading a remote company, I still believe it is the best way to achieve. It was a critical component of our rapid success and remains so for our continued growth. 

My advice to those who want to set a strong foundation for a remote (fully or hybrid) model is to give folks the tools they need to achieve. To work well, you need a way to work — regardless of where you are doing it. 

Here is what I suggest to leaders: 

1. Create the culture: Culture becomes something that belongs to everyone and motivates teammates to contribute in a meaningful way. 

2. Do it your way: A distinguishing factor of great companies is that there is a pre-defined way of working that everyone follows — a clear path forward with no time wasted on pondering how to do the work. 

3. Share information: I am always surprised by how many people tell me that there is little to no documentation or shared plans at their organization. Every team needs a playbook for success.

4. Gather together: Bonding leads to trust, which leads to better collaboration. This is why I suggest that all remote teams get everyone together in person a few times a year to create social connections.

5. Never stop improving: You will get it wrong sometimes. Model your dedication to continually improving by actively seeking out feedback from the team. 

I wrote about this in more detail here: https://lnkd.in/gacbN7-r

Do you feel like the system of setting goals is broken?

In her new book, "Tiny Experiments," neuroscientist Anne-Laure Le Cunff, PhD argues that instead of setting SMART goals, you should be making PACTs with yourself.

Le Cunff defines a pact as “an actionable commitment you will fulfill for a set period of time.”  She says a pact should follow a simple format:

“I will [action] for [duration].”

The beauty of a pact is that it focuses, not on outcomes, but on process. And through that process often comes new discoveries, unexpected learnings, and true transformation.

A pact should also be a PACT:

Purposeful: It should feel exciting and provide meaning through the learning journey itself.

Actionable: It should be based on actions you can reliably perform, and be doable with your current resources.

Continuous: It should be simply and repeatable, whether it’s every day, every weekend, or every week.

Trackable: Not measurable, but trackable with a simple question: Have you done it or not, yes or no?

Some examples from Le Cunff on pacts you can try, or that can inspire you to create your own:

I will code every day for 100 days.
I will write every weekday for the next six months.
I will run every Sunday for the next six weeks.

Check out my column today in Inc. which explains more about why pacts are so valuable, my personal story of how a pact impacted me, and how you can design your own pact.

How would you feel if you got "fired" from a job that you loved?

That's basically what happened to basketball superstar Luka Doncic, who the Dallas Mavericks traded to the L.A. Lakers in exchange for former Lakers big man Anthony Davis, in what many have called the most shocking trade in NBA history. Doncic is a generational talent who loved playing in Dallas—and, at 25, likely has not yet hit his prime.

There have been tons of stories about why Luka got traded, and who won the trade. (Most say L.A. came out the clear winners; others say the trade was good for both teams.) But what has gotten somewhat lost in everything is this:

Luka is hurt. Not physically, but emotionally.

Luka isn't *just* a basketball savant. He's a young man who, like everyone else, has real feelings and emotions. 

And, according to him, although excited about playing with his hero LeBron James in L.A., Luka got blindsided by this trade, and struggled with leaving Dallas, which he considered "home." 

Well, last night the Lakers played the Mavericks, and Doncic and the Lakers came out on top. After the game, it seemed like reporters were all asking Doncic variations on the same question.
 
“What were the emotions like going into this game?”

Doncic acknowledged this was far from just another game.

He described it as “weird,” “different,” and said he couldn’t even explain the emotions he was dealing with as he saw close friends, teammates with whom he’s “been through wars together.”

Then, in a few short words, Doncic shared something especially poignant, insightful, and deep.

“The closure is going to take a while, I think,” Doncic replied. “It’s not ideal…There were a lot of emotions, but we go little by little.”

“And every day is better.”

There’s a great lesson here in emotional intelligence, the ability to understand and manage emotions, namely, this: 

Losing something important to you hurts. Moving on is a process, and it’s best handled one step at a time.

To dig deeper into this lesson, and learn more about how to use emotional intelligence to deal with negative emotions, check out today's column.

"I take all the blame."

That's what Chiefs QB Patrick Mahomes said last night after his team lost to the Philadelphia Eagles. It was one of the worst blowouts in Super Bowl history.

And it was a powerful lesson in emotional intelligence. Here's why.

Mahomes was responsible for his share of mistakes, including two big ones in the second quarter. He threw two interceptions, both which resulted in touchdowns and left the Chiefs trailing the Eagles: 24-0.

After the game, Mahomes could have tried to shift the blame. 

He could have talked about how hard it is to complete passes when you’re getting chased by large men who want to punish you like you stole something from them. (The Chiefs offensive line allowed the Eagles to sack Mahomes six times, the most in his career.) 

Or, he could have blamed the refs, as he has famously done in the past.

But he didn’t.

“Credit to the Eagles, man,” Mahomes said in his post game press conference. “They played better than us from start to finish.”

“Obviously the turnovers hurt,” Mahomes continued. “I take all the blame for that...It’s hard to come back from that in a Super Bowl."

Over and over, Mahomes put the blame on himself.

“I can’t turn the ball over early in the game when it’s not going our way,” Mahomes said.

“I’ll have to learn from that and try to be better the next opportunity that I hopefully get,” Mahomes said.

“Hopefully we can learn from this…and try to continue to get even better because it’s going to take better football, especially from me in order to try to make a run at another Super Bowl,” Mahomes said.

With these words, Mahomes did more than take ownership of the loss. He taught a brilliant lesson in emotional intelligence, the ability to understand and manage emotions.

Why are Mahomes' comments so remarkable? And what can you learn from them that will help you in business and life?

“The most precious resource we all have is time."
—Steve Jobs

Jobs was right, of course. There’s always more money to be made. But time is finite. Once it’s gone, it’s gone.

Research shows that when you take time for others, everyone benefits.

For example, Gallup discovered that employees whose managers held regular meetings with them were almost three times as likely to be engaged at work than counterparts who had no regular meetings. (Employees who had daily communication with their managers were most engaged.)

Of course, this type of investment takes time. But it’s time well spent.

What about our personal lives?

In a study conducted by psychologists at the University of Zurich, participants were assigned to meet up with three people they cared about in the course of a week, to give them a “gift of time.” (The gift needed to be more than the time they would normally spend with each person). 

When compared with another group who wrote about their memories in a daily journal, the “time-givers” reported greater happiness. The longer they continued the practice, the more happiness they reported.

So, this week, why don’t you plan your own gift of time? 

Simply:

1️⃣ Pick a person you’d like to give some time to; then
2️⃣ Plan to do something with that person.

It could be:

💡 Inviting someone for a meal, or even just for ☕ 
👋 A surprise visit
☀️ Meeting for a walk outside
🖥️ A virtual call 
🥳 A morning or afternoon off to spend together

One more thing to keep in mind...

You hardly remember the time you spend alone. But you definitely remember the time you spend with others. 

Meaning, by simply sharing your time with others, you make an investment:

You’re creating memories for the future.

So, remember:

Time is the most precious resource you have. Spend it wisely by sharing it with others.

Because once time is gone, you’re never getting it back.

Ever feel stuck and unable to make a decision or move forward?

Here's a brilliant 3-word phrase that'll help you make quicker, better decisions:

"Run the experiment."

Why is this phrase so helpful?

First of all, it’s important to remember that thinking is not the same as OVER-thinking. Thinking things through is good.

But overthinking is bad because:

-Life rarely plays out exactly the way you’ve imagined it. 

-You spend hours, days, even months or years worrying about things that will never happen.

-It paralyzes you and prevents you from moving forward.

In contrast, when you run the experiment, you take this approach:

"I'm not sure of the right way. But I won't know unless I make a decision.

"So, let's pick one. If it works out great, awesome. If not, I'll have more data and can adjust—or, will know what to do next time."

There are very few irreversible decisions. When you run the experiment, you choose to move forward, rather than standing still. 

And since time is money, standing still often costs more than changing your mind.

As you run more and more experiments, you'll get into a repeated cycle of:

-think
-decide
-test
-learn
-adjust

That tight feedback loop will help you make better and better decisions over time.

So, the next time you find yourself overthinking, take a step back and...

Run the experiment.

Because the more experiments you run, the better decisions you’ll make.

Is empathy good or bad? 

The answer may surprise you.

I’ve been told I’m a very empathetic person. I always considered that a strength...

And it is, if kept in balance.

Don't get me wrong—I think we need more empathy in the world. Empathy helps us to understand and relate to others.

But here's the thing: If you leave your empathy unchecked, it'll take a heavy toll. That's because you can't really turn empathy "off." 

When others pour out their hearts to me, I take it all in. Unable to turn off my feelings, I’m often left feeling emotionally drained. And I'm not alone.

Research shows that nurses who work with terminally ill patients run a high risk of developing "compassion fatigue," a condition of physical and emotional depletion. It’s easy for caregivers like these to focus on the needs of their patients at the expense of their own, putting them on a path to burnout.

We can compare empathy to a muscle. Used in the right way, it allows you to “lift” others up and even help carry their burdens. But like any muscle, it can become overworked.

The key, then, is to develop emotionally intelligent empathy—balanced empathy that works for you, instead of against you.

How can you exercise your empathy muscle in an emotionally intelligent way?

A few tips: 

1. Give yourself buffer time.
If your job involves being around others much of the day, you may quickly find yourself emotionally exhausted.

To combat this, schedule buffer time between meetings or time with others. Take shorter, more frequent breaks that allow you to recharge your emotional batteries.

2. Set boundaries.
If you're spending time with someone who you know needs more than usual attention, set a time limit. You might even make an appointment that you have to meet at a certain time—even if it's an appointment with yourself.

Of course, you don't want to rush away...but recognize that if every time you're with them you overspend your emotional budget, you'll probably start avoiding them altogether.

Your empathy muscle can be a major source of strength—but only if you don’t work it to the point of breakdown.

So, work to understand your own emotional needs; then, act accordingly. 

That's that's emotionally intelligent empathy—empathy that helpful, instead of harmful.

I'm a 45-yr old father of four.

For years, I allowed my emotions to get the best of me. 

But after 2500+ hours studying the psychology of emotional intelligence, I built a toolkit of frameworks to help me keep my cool and make better decisions during emotional moments.

Here are 3 frameworks that'll change your life:

1. The 3-Question Rule

Years ago I was watching an interview with comedian Craig Ferguson. He made a funny but very insightful joke:

There are three things you must always ask yourself before you say anything:

-Does this need to be said?
-Does this need to be said by me?
-Does this need to be said by me, now?

Ferguson quipped it took him three marriages to learn this lesson. 

But all joking aside, I use this rule every day, and it's saved me more times than I can count.

2. The Blue Dolphin Rule

The Blue Dolphin Rule is a solution to the "White Bear Problem," also known as ironic process theory. 

The problem was developed by Harvard psychologist Daniel Wegner and refers to a quote by Russian writer Fyodor Dostoevsky:

"Try to pose for yourself this task: not to think of a polar bear, and you will see that the cursed thing will come to mind every minute."

Over time, psychologists identified one of the most effective solutions to the white bear problem was to replace unwanted thoughts with desired thoughts. 

I call these desired thoughts "Blue Dolphins."

For example, if you're getting nervous before a big presentation, you can replace disquieting thoughts with a more encouraging one: 

White Bear: "I'm so nervous. I'm so nervous. I'm so nervous."

Blue Dolphin: "I'm so excited. I've prepared well. This is going to go great."

3. The Golden Question

The golden question is actually five questions in one. 

When you need to make a decision under pressure or stress, ask yourself:

How will I feel about this in:

-a day?
-a week?
-a month?
-a year?
-5 years?

The Golden Question helps you keep things in perspective. AND it gives you a glimpse into the future—so you make better, more well-rounded decisions you don't later regret.
